                                                                                                                                HALF HOUR RECREATIONS
                                                                                                                                          IN POPULAR SCIENCE.
                                                                                                                                              8ECOND SERIES.
                                                                                                                           J,   ®n ths     Transmission of $ound kg tho
                                                                                                                                               $.tmosphm.
                                                                                                                                    By John Tynda1x, D. C. L.,   IX.   D., F. R. S.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:29 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                                'HIS  notice embraces the scientific results of an inquiry
                                                                                                                           X     on fog-signals, undertaken at the instance of the Elder
                                                                                                                          Brethren of the Trinity House, and communicated, with
                                                                                                                          their friendly concurrence, to the Royal Society.
                                                                                                                            The investigation was begun on May 19, 1873, and con
                                                                                                                          tinued tillJuly 4. It was resumed on October 8, and con
                                                                                                                          tinued to the end of November. It also includes observations
                                                                                                                          made during the dense fog which enveloped London on
                                                                                                                          December 9 and the succeeding days.
                                                                                                                            Gongs and bells were excluded from this investigation, in
                                                                                                                          consequence of their proved inferiority to other instruments
                                                                                                                          of signalling. The experiments were made with trumpets
                                                                                                                          blown by powerfully compressed air, with steam-whistles,
                                                                                                                          guns, and a steam-siren, associated with a trumpet sixteen
                                                                                                                          feet long.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                             DabolPs horn, or trumpet, had been highly spoken of by
                                                                                                                          writers on fog-signals. A third-order apparatus of the kind
                                                                                                                          had been reported as sending its sound to a distance of from
                                                                                                                          seven to nine miles against the wind, and to a distance of
                                                                                                                          twelve to fourteen miles with the wind. Holmes had im

                                                                                                                          2          RECREATIONS IN POPULAR SCIENCE.              [Tyndau.
                                                                                                                          proved upon Daboll ; and with two instruments of Holmes
                                                                                                                          — not of the third, but of the first order — our experiments
                                                                                                                          were made. On May 19, at three miles distance, they
                                                                                                                          became useless as a fog-signal ; at a distance of four miles,
                                                                                                                          with paddles stopped and all on board quiet, they were
                                                                                                                          wholly unheard. At a distance of two miles from the Fore
                                                                                                                          land the whistles tested on May 19 became useless.        The
                                                                                                                          twelve-o'clock gun, fired with a one-pound charge at Drop
                                                                                                                          Fort in Dover, was well heard on May 19, when the horns
                                                                                                                          and whistles were inaudible.     On May 20 the permeability
                                                                                                                          of the atmosphere had somewhat increased, but the steam-
                                                                                                                          whistle failed to pierce it to a depth of three miles. At four
                                                                                                                          miles the horns, though aided by quietness on board, were
                                                                                                                          barely heard. By careful nursing, if I may use the expres
                                                                                                                          sion, the horn-sounds were carried to a distance of six miles.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:29 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          The superiority of the eighteen-pounder gun, already em
                                                                                                                          ployed by the Trinity House as a fog-signal, over horns
                                                                                                                          and whistles, was on this day so decided as almost to war
                                                                                                                          rant its recommendation    to the exclusion   of all   the other
                                                                                                                          signals.
                                                                                                                            Nothing occurred on June 2 to exalt our hopes of the trum
                                                                                                                          pets and whistles.  The horns were scarcely heard at a dis
                                                                                                                          tance of three miles; sometimes, indeed, they failed to be
                                                                                                                          heard at two miles.   By keeping everything quiet on board,
                                                                                                                          they were afterwards heard to a distance of six miles — a
                                                                                                                          result, however, mainly due to the improved condition of the
                                                                                                                          atmosphere.    Considering the demands as to sound-range
                                                                                                                          made by writers on this subject, the demonstrated incompe
                                                                                                                          tence of horns and whistles of great reputed power to meet
                                                                                                                          these demands was not encouraging.     On June 3 the atmos
                                                                                                                          phere had changed surprisingly. It was loaded overhead with
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          dark and threatening clouds ; the sounds, nevertheless, were
                                                                                                                          well heard beyond nine miles. On June 10 the acoustic
                                                                                                                          transparency of the air was also very fair, the distance pene
                                                                                                                          trated being upwards of eight miles and three quarters. The
                                                                                                                          subsidence of the sound near the boundary of the acoustic
                                                                                                                                                       2

                                                                                                                          Tyndall.]         transmission of sound.                      3
                                                                                                                          shadow      on the   Dover side of the Foreland, and before
                                                                                                                          entering the shadow, was to-day sudden and extraordinary,
                                                                                                                           affecting equally both horns and guns. We were warned on
                                                                                                                          June 3 that the supremacy of the gun on one occasion by no
                                                                                                                          means implied its supremacy on all occasions, the self-same
                                                                                                                          guns which on May 20 had so far transcended the horns
                                                                                                                          being on this day their equals, and nothing more. June 1 1
                                                                                                                          was employed in mastering still further the facts relating to
                                                                                                                          the subsidence of the sound east and west of the Foreland ;
                                                                                                                          the cause of this subsidence being in part due to the weaken
                                                                                                                          ing of the sonorous waves by their divergence into the sound
                                                                                                                          shadow, and in part to interference.
                                                                                                                             The atmosphere on June 25 was again very defective
                                                                                                                          acoustically. The sounds reached a maximum distance of six
                                                                                                                          miles and a half ; but at four miles, on returning from the
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:29 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          maximum distance, they were very faint. The day had, as
                                                                                                                          it were, darkened acoustically.    On this day the guns lost
                                                                                                                          still further their preeminence, and at five miles and a half
                                                                                                                          were inferior to the horn.         No sounds whatever reached
                                                                                                                          Dover Pier on the nth ; and it was only towards the close
                                                                                                                          of the day that they succeeded in reaching it on the 25th.
                                                                                                                          Thus by slow degrees the caprices of the atmosphere made
                                                                                                                          themselves known to us, showing us subsequently that within
                                                                                                                          the limits of a single day, even within a single minute, the
                                                                                                                          air, as a vehicle of sound, underwent most serious variations.
                                                                                                                          June    26 was a far better day than its predecessor, the acous
                                                                                                                          tic   range being over nine miles and a quarter.     The direc
                                                                                                                          tion of the wind was less favorable to the sound on this day
                                                                                                                          than on the preceding one, plainly proving that something
                                                                                                                          else than the wind must play an important part in shorten
                                                                                                                          ing the sound-range.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                             On July 1, we experimented upon a rotating horn, and
                                                                                                                          heard its direct or axial blast, which proved to be the strong
                                                                                                                          est, at a distance of ten miles and a half.       The sounds
                                                                                                                          were also heard at the Varne light-ship, which is twelve miles
                                                                                                                          and three quarters from the Foreland. The atmosphere had
                                                                                                                                                         3

                                                                                                                                   RECREATIONS IN POPULAR SCIENCE.               [Tyndal*.
                                                                                                                          become decidedly clearer acoustically, but not so optically ;
                                                                                                                          for on this day thick haze obscured the white cliffs of the
                                                                                                                          Foreland. In fact, on days of far greater optical purity, the
                                                                                                                          sound had failed to reach one third of the distance attained
                                                                                                                          to-day. In the light of such a fact, any attempt to make
                                                                                                                          optical transparency a measure of acoustic transparency
                                                                                                                          must be seen to be delusive.         On July I, a twelve-inch
                                                                                                                          American whistle, of which we had heard a highly favora
                                                                                                                          ble account, was tried in place of the twelve-inch English
                                                                                                                          whistle ; but, like its predecessor, the performance of the new
                                                                                                                          instrument fell behind that of the horns.     An interval of
                                                                                                                          twelve hours sufficed to convert the acoustically clear atmos
                                                                                                                          phere of July 1 into an opaque one ; for on July 2 even the
                                                                                                                          horn-sounds, with paddles stopped, and all noiseless on board,
                                                                                                                          could not penetrate farther than four miles.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:29 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                             Thus each succeeding day provided us with a virtually
                                                                                                                          new atmosphere, clearly showing that conclusions founded
                                                                                                                          upon one day's observations might utterly break down in the
                                                                                                                          presence of the phenomena of another day.      This was most
                                                                                                                          impressively demonstrated on the day now to be referred to.
                                                                                                                          The acoustic impewiousness of July 3 was found to be still
                                                                                                                          greater than that of July 2, while the optical purity of the
                                                                                                                          day was sensibly perfect. The cliffs of the Foreland could
                                                                                                                          be seen to-day at ten times the distance at which they ceased
                                                                                                                          to be visible on July I, while the sounds were cut off at one
                                                                                                                          sixth of the distance. At two P. M. neither guns nor trum
                                                                                                                          pets were able to pierce the transparent air to a depth of
                                                                                                                          three, hardly to a depth of two miles.     This extraordinary
                                                                                                                          opacity we consider to arise from the irregular admixture
                                                                                                                          with the air of the aqueous vapor raised by a powerful sun.
                                                                                                                          This vapor, though perfectly invisible, produced an acoustic
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          cloud impervious to the sound, and from which the sound
                                                                                                                          waves were thrown back as the waves of light are from an
                                                                                                                          ordinary cloud.  The waves thus refusing transmission, pro
                                                                                                                          duced by  their reflection echoes of extraordinary strength
                                                                                                                          and duration.   This we may remark is the first time that
                                                                                                                                                         4

                                                                                                                          Tyndall.]         transmission    OF SOUND.                  5
                                                                                                                          audible echoes    have been proved to be reflected from an
                                                                                                                          optically   transparent atmosphere.   By the lowering of the
                                                                                                                          sun the production    of the vapor was checked, and the trans-
                                                                                                                          missive power of the atmosphere restored to such an extent
                                                                                                                          that, at a distance of two miles from the Foreland, at seven
                                                                                                                          P. M., the intensity of the sound was at least thirty-six times
                                                                                                                          its intensity at two P. M.
                                                                                                                             On October 8 the observations were resumed, a steam
                                                                                                                          siren and a Canadian whistle of great power being added to
                                                                                                                          the listof instruments. A boiler had its steam raised to a
                                                                                                                          pressure of seventy pounds to the square inch ; on opening a

Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:29 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          causing a disk with twelve radial slits to rotate behind a
                                                                                                                          fixed disk with the same number of slits. When the slits

                                                                                                                            This, I say, expresses the opinion generally entertained,
                                                                                                                          "clear still air" being regarded as the best vehicle for sound.
                                                                                                                          We have not, as stated above, experimented in really dense
                                                                                                                          fogs ; but the experiments actually made entirely destroy the
                                                                                                                          notion that clear weather is necessarily better for the trans
                                                                                                                          mission of sound than thick weather.     Some of our days of
                                                                                                                          densest acoustic opacity have been marvellously clear opti
                                                                                                                          cally, while some of our days of thick haze have shown
                                                                                                                          themselves highly favorable to the transmission of sound.
                                                                                                                          Were the physical cause of the sound-waste that above
                                                                                                                          assigned, did that waste arise in any material degree from
                                                                                                                          reflection at the limiting surfaces of the particles of haze, this
                                                                                                                          result would be inexplicable.
                                                                                                                             Again, Derham, as quoted by Sir John Herschel, says that
                                                                                                                          " falling rain tends powerfully to obstruct sound." We have
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:29 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          had repeated reversals of this conclusion.      Some of our ob
                                                                                                                          servations have been made on days when rain and hail
                                                                                                                          descended with a perfectly tropical fury ; and in no single
                                                                                                                          case did the rain deaden the sound    ;   in every case, indeed, it
                                                                                                                          had precisely the opposite effect.
                                                                                                                             But falling snow, according to Derham, offers a more
                                                                                                                          serious obstacle than any other meteorological agent to the
                                                                                                                          transmission of sound. We have not extended our observa
                                                                                                                          tions at the South Foreland into snowy weather ; but an
                                                                                                                          observation of my own, made on December 29, in the Alps,
                                                                                                                          during   aheavy snow-storm, distinctly negatives the state
                                                                                                                          ment of Derham.
                                                                                                                            Reverting to the case of fog, I am unable in modern ob
                                                                                                                          servations to discover anything conclusive as to its alleged
                                                                                                                          power of deadening sound.       Ihad the pleasure of listening
                                                                                                                          to a very interesting lecture on fog-signals, delivered by Mr.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Beazeley before the United-Service Institution ; and       I
                                                                                                                                                                                    have
                                                                                                                          carefully perused the printed report of that lecture, and of a
                                                                                                                          paper previously communicated by Mr. Beazeley to the Insti
                                                                                                                          tution of Civil Engineers.  But in neither of these pains

                                                                                                                          Tvndall.]      TRANSMISSION        OF SOUND.
                                                                                                                          taking compilations can I find any adequate evidence of the
                                                                                                                          alleged power of fogs to deaden sound.
                                                                                                                             Mr. Douglass stated that he had found in his experience
                                                                                                                          but little difference in the travelling of sound in foggy or
                                                                                                                          in clear weather. He had distinctly heard in a fog, at the
                                                                                                                          Smalls rock in the Bristol Channel, guns fired at Milford
                                                                                                                          Haven, twenty-five miles away.  Mr. Beazeley, moreover,
                                                                                                                          has heard the Lundy-Island gun
                                                                                                                                                           " at Hartland Point," a
                                                                                                                          distance of ten miles, during dense fog.    Mr. Beazeley's
                                                                                                                          conclusion,  indeed, accurately expresses the state of our
                                                                                                                          knowledge when he wrote, in winding up his paper, he
                                                                                                                          admitted " that the subject appeared to be very little known,
                                                                                                                          and that the more it was looked into the more apparent
                                                                                                                          became the fact that the evidence as to the effect of fog
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:29 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          upon sound is extremely conflicting."   -When, therefore, it is
                                                                                                                          alleged, as it is so often, that the power of fogs to deaden
                                                                                                                          sound is well known, the disjunctive not is to be inserted
                                                                                                                          before the predicate.
                                                                                                                            The real enemy to the transmission of sound through the
                                                                                                                          atmosphere has,   I think, been clearly revealed by the fore
                                                                                                                          going inquiry. That enemy has been proved to be not rain,
                                                                                                                          nor hail, nor haze, nor fog, nor snow — not water, in fact, in
                                                                                                                          either a liquid or a solid form — but water in a vaporous
                                                                                                                          form mingled with air so as to render it acoustically turbid
                                                                                                                          and flocculent.   This acoustic turbidity often occurs on days
                                                                                                                          of surprising optical transparency. Any system of measures,
                                                                                                                          therefore, founded on the assumption that the optical and
                                                                                                                          acoustic transparency of the atmosphere go hand in hand,
                                                                                                                          must prove delusive.
                                                                                                                            There is but one solution to this difficulty ; it is to make
                                                                                                                          the source of sound so powerful as to be able to endure loss
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          by partial reflection and still retain a sufficient residue for
                                                                                                                          transmission.   Of all the instruments hitherto examined by
                                                                                                                          us, the siren comes nearest to the fulfilment of this condi
                                                                                                                          tion  and its establishment upon our coasts will, in my opin
                                                                                                                                 ;
                                                                                                                          ion, prove an incalculable boon to the mariner.

                                                                                                                          THAT   for our consideration, equalling or even surpassing

                                                                                                                          nized as the ordinary arms. The Calamaries or Squids,

                                                                                                                          one      of   these   creatures destroyed on the coast   of Spain by

                                                                                                                          however, are at present not very extensive. The fact of

                                                                                                                                               By Alexander Braun.
                                                                                                                                      there is nothing " new under the sun," may be
                                                                                                                          THAT  a true adage in other respects, but to the history of
                                                                                                                          nature and our knowledge of it this saying cannot well be
                                                                                                                          applied.   Here one new thing is succeeded by another,
                                                                                                                          often, to be sure, in accordance with what we look for and
                                                                                                                          expect, but not less frequently in a manner surprising and
                                                                                                                          not anticipated ; and in order to ally the new with the old,
                                                                                                                          the latter itself requires repeated   transformation.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:29 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                             The progress of science resembles the progress which
                                                                                                                          nature herself has made in her course of development; but
                                                                                                                          the great transformations in the history of nature's develop
                                                                                                                          ment proceed slowly, and this produces within the single
                                                                                                                          epochs in which they occur the semblance of a stand-still,
                                                                                                                          or, more correctly speaking, of a circular movement in which
                                                                                                                          the same occurrences are repeated again and again.
                                                                                                                             Up to the end of the last century the state of natural sci
                                                                                                                          ence could indeed admit of the supposition that nature had
                                                                                                                          proceeded in that completeness which she now exhibits to
                                                                                                                          our eyes, from the Creator's hand, remaining essentially
                                                                                                                          unchanged throughout the subsequent ages, a work of admi
                                                                                                                          rable perfection from the beginning, without any progress
                                                                                                                          of further development. This supposition at the same time
                                                                                                                          found its support in one of the most ancient historical and
                                                                                                                          religious documents of mankind in the Mosaic history of
                                                                                                                          creation, where it is said that " God saw everything that he
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          had made, and, behold, it was very good."     But the ancient
                                                                                                                          documents which nature herself has preserved in the inte
                                                                                                                          rior of the earth, and which the archaeologists of natural
                                                                                                                          science, the geologists, and palaeontologists have zealously
                                                                                                                          been endeavoring to gradually decipher for us, have taught
                                                                                                                                                           1
                                                                                                                                         3

                                                                                                                                   RECREATIONS IN POPULAR SCIENCE.                  [Bkaun.
                                                                                                                          us  differently.   They have incontrovertibly demonstrated
                                                                                                                          that the earth as a whole, as well as the most minute crea
                                                                                                                          ture upon  it, has a history of growth and development    that
                                                                                                                                                                                    ;
                                                                                                                          in nature not less than in the life of men, perfection must be
                                                                                                                          striven and contended for on  a long path, and can be gained
                                                                                                                          only by degrees  ; that consequently what we are accustomed
                                                                                                                          to call creation, must be looked for and understood, not only
                                                                                                                          at the beginning of the existence of things, but within the
                                                                                                                          histo1y of their development.
                                                                                                                             A passing glance at the mighty transformations which
                                                                                                                          living nature has undergone in the course of this develop
                                                                                                                          ment, may introduce us to the special subject of this disqui
                                                                                                                          sition.

                                                                                                                          extent of the glaciers from the traces which they have left

                                                                                                                             What are generally called, as to their appearance from a
                                                                                                                          distance, snow and ice bergs, are, on closer observation, to be
                                                                                                                          distinguished as two essentiallly different parts. The sum
                                                                                                                          mits of mountains extending beyond the line of perpetual
                                                                                                                          snow,     far as they do not consist of rugged masses of rock,
                                                                                                                                    as
                                                                                                                          to which the snow does not adhere, are covered with a never-
                                                                                                                          disappearing snow, which, however, by the alternation be
                                                                                                                          tween melting and recongelation at the surface, assumes a

                                                                                                                          is found in richest abundance in the lower ridges between
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:29 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          the higher mountain-ridges in snow-fields, known under the
                                                                                                                          name of Firnseas, and in the troughs with which the high
                                                                                                                          valleys for the most part commence, and which, on account
                                                                                                                          of their shape, are sometimes called " circus." Into these
                                                                                                                          troughs the snow is, as it were, swept by the winds, and
                                                                                                                          piled up in great masses.      Under the weight of the upper
                                                                                                                          layers the lower  ones  begin to yield, and to move downward
                                                                                                                          towards the valley upon the inclined plane underlying them.
                                                                                                                          Here are the starting-points, the sources, as it were, of the
                                                                                                                          glaciers, which have a similar origin as the avalanches, with
                                                                                                                          only this difference, that they are not precipitated with
                                                                                                                          storm-like rapidity, but glide downward with a slowness
                                                                                                                          that escapes immediate observation.        The granulous firn-
                                                                                                                          snow is, during this process, by alternate melting and con
                                                                                                                          gealing, transformed more and more into solid ice, which at
                                                                                                                          first appears still rich in air-bubbles, and white, but which
                                                                                                                          at last, in the lower portions of the glacier, becomes homo
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          geneous and of vitreous transparency, exhibiting an incom
                                                                                                                          parable purity, and in the crevices and clefts that wonderful
                                                                                                                          azure coloration which lightly plays into the green, and is so
                                                                                                                          much           and praised by all travellers in the Alps.
                                                                                                                                    admired
                                                                                                                          Often many glaciers rise from one Firnsea, radiating in dif
                                                                                                                                                        19

                                                                                                                                   RECREATIONS IN POPULAR SCIENCE.                   [Beaun.
                                                                                                                          ferent directions, and stretching, like long arms, down into
                                                                                                                          the valleys, in which they often descend, as far as four thou
                                                                                                                          sand, even five thousand feet below the snow-line, bordered
                                                                                                                          by flowery walls of rocks or grass-meadows, or reaching down
                                                                                                                          to the wood-region,    sometimes even approaching inhabited
                                                                                                                          villages, orchards,  and grain fields.
                                                                                                                              The glaciers, therefore, are no icebergs, but currents of ice
                                                                                                                          which fill the valleys. And, indeed, their comparison to cur
                                                                                                                          rents is no empty word. A glacier bears, indeed, in many
                                                                                                                          respects, the same characteristics as a stream ; it moves in an
                                                                                                                          imperceptible flow, and would descend farther and farther
                                                                                                                          into the valley if the melting of the lower extremity did not
                                                                                                                          put a limit to the advance.     In wet and cold years it hap
                                                                                                                          pens that the glaciers actually advance down the valley, often
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:29 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          to a distance  of fifty feet and more during one summer ;
                                                                                                                          while, vice versa, in very warm years the glaciers often per
                                                                                                                          ceptibly recede, i. e., grow shorter. This change is to be
                                                                                                                          accounted for by the difference in the relation of the forces
                                                                                                                          which produce and destroy the glacier.        If both balance
                                                                                                                          each other, the \glacier seems to be at a stand-still. For, on
                                                                                                                          the one hand, the glaciers are fed by the snow-falls in the
                                                                                                                          region of the Firnseas and Houghs, in which they have their
                                                                                                                          source, and by the constant advance, as well as the pushing
                                                                                                                          together; of the icy mass from thence downward, and consid
                                                                                                                          erably less by snow-falls in the lower region ; on the other
                                                                                                                          hand, a destructive and diminishing influence is exerted in
                                                                                                                          a less measure by evaporation, to a greater extent (which
                                                                                                                          more and more increases in the lower regions) by melting,
                                                                                                                          especially at the surface, under the influence of the warmer
                                                                                                                          air, but also at the bottom.    How powerful the effect of this
                                                                                                                          liquefaction  is, is proved by the mighty water-currents which
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          flow in tunnel-like courses under the strong ice-roof, and
                                                                                                                          which collect not only the water forming at the bottom
                                                                                                                          itself, but also that which trickles down from the surface
                                                                                                                          through crevices and clefts, until at last they flow out of the
                                                                                                                          lower extremity of the glacier through high-arched exits, the
                                                                                                                                                         20

                                                                                                                           Braon,]                 THE GLACIAL EPOCH.                   53
                                                                                                                          so-called glacier-gates. In consequence of this liquefaction
                                                                                                                          the glaciers would necessarily be forced back by degrees to
                                                                                                                          the boundaries of perpetual snow, and thus entirely de
                                                                                                                          stroyed, if the waste which they suffer were not constantly
                                                                                                                          repaired by yielding from above.        According to what
                                                                                                                           has    been   said, some    might think that the glaciers were
                                                                                                                          undergoing a regular        increase in winter, and as regular a
                                                                                                                          diminution in summer.   That this, however, is not the case,
                                                                                                                          is accounted for by the fact that the movement of the ice
                                                                                                                          which produces its advance does not entirely cease in win
                                                                                                                          ter, to be sure, but yet is from three to four times slower        .
                                                                                                                          than in summer.
                                                                                                                             The movement of the glacier follows similar laws as that
                                                                                                                          of rivers. It is more rapid in the centre of the glacier than
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:29 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          at its sides, where it is retarded by friction ; and likewise
                                                                                                                          more rapid towards the surface than at the bottom, where
                                                                                                                          it is retarded by friction against its bed ; it increases at a
                                                                                                                          greater inclination of the plane of the bottom, while it is
                                                                                                                          obstructed and retarded by an occasional rising of the bed of
                                                                                                                          the valley and by promontories projecting into the valley.
                                                                                                                          The glacier follows in its movement all the sinuosities and
                                                                                                                          windings of the valley, like     a    river
                                                                                                                                                                  smaller glaciers join at
                                                                                                                                                                        ;

                                                                                                                            Glaciers are masses of ice through which coarser and finer
                                                                                                                          veins of water percolate, and the inner temperature of which
                                                                                                                          consequently remains always at the freezing point, as in all
                                                                                                                          mixtures of ice and water.    The pressure which the upper
                                                                                                                          layers exert upon the lower ones results, on the one hand, in
                                                                                                                          the formation of innumerable cracks, as fine as hair, which
                                                                                                                          lessen the cohesion, and on the other hand in a slight lower
                                                                                                                          ing of the freezing point of the ice exposed to the pressure.
                                                                                                                          Such a lowering can only take place when free heat is con
                                                                                                                          verted into latent heat; that is, when some of the ice melts,
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:29 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          and is converted into water.    Since water is less expanded
                                                                                                                          than ice, space is gained in which the molecules of ice can
                                                                                                                          yield to the pressure exerted upon them, and change their
                                                                                                                          places. The surrounding water, being now able to give
                                                                                                                          way and flow off, is not pressed, and does not participate in
                                                                                                                          the lowering of the freezing point ; consequently water of o°
                                                                                                                          comes into contact with ice of less than o°, the effect of
                                                                                                                          which is   arecongelation of the surrounding water, while at
                                                                                                                          the same time the portions which had been separated by pres
                                                                                                                          sure are reunited and kept together bv the recongealed water,
                                                                                                                          which forms a kind of cement between them. This process,
                                                                                                                          which is continuously repeated in the interior of the glacier,
                                                                                                                          gives ductility and movability to its ice.       A well-known
                                                                                                                          phenomenon,    first observed  by Faraday    in 1850, according
                                                                                                                          to which two pieces of thawing ice, when pressed together,

                                                                                                                          torn, rough and angular.     If this boundary-line is traced up
                                                                                                                          the valley, it is finally seen to coincide with the boundary-

                                                                                                                          received such lines or scratches ; nay, the scratched stones

                                                                                                                          lose their characteristic etchings. Scratched stones therefore

                                                                                                                          partly rounded off, polished, and scratched, partly angular
                                                                                                                          and sharp-edged (especially so the larger ones), are found
                                                                                                                          mixed in them, without order, with finer sand and debris.
