                                                                                                                          A Lecture  by Professor Balfour Stewart, F. R. S., delivered           in
                                                                                                                                the Hulme Town Hall, Manchester, November 13, 1872.
                                                                                                                              WILL,       first   of all, ask you   to accompany me into a place
                                                                                                                          J_ with which           we are all more or less familiar   — I mean   the
                                                                                                                          room in which an engine does its work. Perhaps we are
                                                                                                                          struck with the vast display of power before us, and with
                                                                                                                          the noise and tumult that are the accompaniments of such
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:30 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          power ; for, in truth, an engine is a great worker, and we
                                                                                                                          are none of us slow to take advantage of the fruits of its
                                                                                                                          industry.  The engine will probably be a steam engine ; it
                                                                                                                          may possibly be an air engine ; at any rate, it will be a
                                                                                                                          heat engine.  Now, what are the conditions under which
                                                                                                                          such an engine works?      In all engines two things are
                                                                                                                          necessary.   We must, first  of all, have a hot chamber ;
                                                                                                                          then we must have a cold chamber, and the engine will
                                                                                                                          produce work in the process of carrying heat from the
                                                                                                                          hot chamber to the cold. These are the essentials. The
                                                                                                                          cranks, and wheels, and cylinders, and pistons are conven
                                                                                                                          iences, but they are not really essential ; we can conceive of
                                                                                                                          an engine without them. Let us take an ordinary low-pres
                                                                                                                          sure engine.   Here we have a boiler and a condenser, and
                                                                                                                          as the engine works the heat is carried from the boiler to
                                                                                                                          the condenser.   Now, in order to show you that this is the
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          case, and that'the heat must be carried from a hot substance
                                                                                                                          to a cold one, let us consider an engine            of quite
                                                                                                                                                                             a different
                                                                                                                          kind —      I
                                                                                                                                     mean an ordinary fire or flue, for an ordinary fire
                                                                                                                          is, to some extent, an engine. You have in it the production
                                                                                                                          of mechanical effect in the process of carrying heat from a
                                                                                                                          hot substance to a cold.            In an ordinary fire we have the

                                                                                                                                    RECREATIONS IN POPULAR SCIENCE.               [Stewart.
                                                                                                                          hot air rushing up the chimney from the fire, and mingling
                                                                                                                          with the cold air above ; that is, we have the carrying of
                                                                                                                          heat from a hot substance to a cold ; the hot current of air
                                                                                                                          rushing up the chimney and mingling with the cold air out
                                                                                                                          side.   And   an   engine   of    kind — for it is an engine
                                                                                                                                                           the
                                                                                                                          — really produces work, and you might take advantage of the
                                                                                                                          current of air that is going up the chimney ; indeed, an ordi
                                                                                                                          nary fire is a ventilating engine, and will do very often the
                                                                                                                          work of ventilation that would otherwise require an ordinary
                                                                                                                          engine.
                                                                                                                            Now, let    us consider  two great heat engines ; one I may
                                                                                                                          call the Earth engine, and the other the Sun engine.      Let us
                                                                                                                          consider first of all our own earth as a heat engine.   Here is
                                                                                                                          a model of the earth.     [Exhibiting a globe.]  You  all  know

                                                                                                                          twenty-four hours, and that the equator, or the central part
                                                                                                                          between the two poles of the earth, is that particular region
                                                                                                                          on which the sun shines very directly ; whereas, on the other
                                                                                                                          hand, the poles are the regions where the sun hardly shines
                                                                                                                          at all.  The equatorial regions are the boilers of this heat
                                                                                                                          engine, and the pole is its condenser; and this engine — for
                                                                                                                          it is an engine — works in the process of carrying hot air from

                                                                                                                          the heated air finds its way in the upper regions of the atmos

                                                                                                                                                  By J. W. Phelps.
                                                                                                                          AS
                                                                                                                                   matter exists in three very distinct forms, solid, liquid,
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:30 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                                  and gaseous, so force may exhibit itself in a variety
                                                                                                                          of forms.    Thus heat, electricity, magnetism, gravitation,
                                                                                                                          may be different expressions of one and the same force ; and
                                                                                                                          this force may be accurately measured in feet and inches.
                                                                                                                          As it can be told to a certainty what the intensity is, of the
                                                                                                                          earth's attraction at any point of a right line, leading indefi
                                                                                                                          nitely from its centre, so the exact distance, in miles, can be
                                                                                                                          ascertained at which a break occurs in a submarine cable.
                                                                                                                          The force measured in the first case is called gravitation, and
                                                                                                                          in the second electricity.   The laws governing both, in their
                                                                                                                          relation   of distance and intensity, are precisely the same.
                                                                                                                          Both vary in the energy of their action inversely as the
                                                                                                                          squares of the distances.
                                                                                                                            Perhaps the original form of all force is vibration. Let
                                                                                                                          it be supposed that, under the effect of vibration, one atom
                                                                                                                          moves upwards and another downwards, or in any other
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          opposite directions.    Now, if the two atoms be directly
                                                                                                                          opposed, and are under an equal impulse, their opposing
                                                                                                                          force will be neutralized, and changed to some other form ;
                                                                                                                          but if the opposition of the two atoms, instead of being
                                                                                                                          direct, in the same straight line, should occur in parallel
                                                                                                                          lines, the two not butting squarely together, then the result
                                                                                                                                                         21

                                                                                                                                     RECREATIONS IN POPULAR SCIENCE.                  [Phelps.
                                                                                                                          would be   awhirling motion, like that of the couples in me
                                                                                                                          chanics.   And such is the motion which often arises from
                                                                                                                          the action of that form of force which we call electricity
                                                                                                                          on finely comminuted matter.
                                                                                                                             The form of force which first brings nebulous or star-mat
                                                                                                                          ter together into a whirling vortex is probably electricity,
                                                                                                                          and not gravitation.     It may be conceived that this star-mat
                                                                                                                          ter exists disseminated through a vast portion of space ; that
                                                                                                                          it is, in the first place, thrown into a state of vibration by
                                                                                                                          some prime motion, like that of light, and that through vibra
                                                                                                                          tion the atoms are thrown into the same whirling motion
                                                                                                                          which results from electrical action, and produces the vortex,
                                                                                                                          as seen by the telescope.   How     a   central sun and its revolv
                                                                                                                          ing planets may be produced from this whirling vortex, we
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:30 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          do not yet fully understand ; but we will leave this branch of
                                                                                                                          the subject for the present, and descend to the consideration
                                                                                                                          of electrical force, as often witnessed upon the face of our
                                                                                                                          globe.
                                                                                                                             The waterspout, the tornado, the whirlwind, the cyclone,
                                                                                                                          and the hurricane, are all doubtless the result of electrical
                                                                                                                          action.  The whirlwind may be seen on almost any dry
                                                                                                                          summer's day, stirring up the dust in a circular motion upon
                                                                                                                          the highway.     This circular motion is sometimes with the
                                                                                                                          hands of the watch, and at other times against them. Tn the
                                                                                                                          valleys and deep basins, dry and elevated, of the Rocky
                                                                                                                          Mountains and the Cordilleras of Mexico, the whirlwind is
                                                                                                                          exhibited in its greatest activity. It occurs there of all sizes,
                                                                                                                          from no more than an inch in diameter up to many hundred
                                                                                                                          times that dimension.    In the deep basins of Mexico, where
                                                                                                                          there is no prevailing current of air, whirlwinds may be seen
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          in the warmer hours of the day, spinning rapidly on their
                                                                                                                          axes, throwing up large columns of dust several hundred feet
                                                                                                                          in height, and remaining as stationary as the sleeping top
                                                                                                                          for a long time. Farther north, in the Rocky Mountains,
                                                                                                                          where south-west breezes prevail, these whirlwinds are gen
                                                                                                                          erally borne along with the wind. The rapidity of their
                                                                                                                                                         22

                                                                                                                          Phelps]    FORCE ELECTRICALLY EXHIBITED.
                                                                                                                          whirling motion, in both cases, is altogether too great to be
                                                                                                                          attributed to any power short of electrical agency. The air
                                                                                                                          outside of a stationary whirlwind is generally quite still,
                                                                                                                          while with the moving whirlwind it often loiters along, only
                                                                                                                          as a five, ten, or fifteen mile breeze. Thus, while the motion
                                                                                                                          of translation of the whirlwind may be only ten miles, or so,
                                                                                                                          an hour, its whirling velocity is often a hundred miles or
                                                                                                                          more an hour. The tornado is a whirlwind which probably
                                                                                                                          whirls at the rate of a hundred and fifty miles an hour ; for
                                                                                                                          it is only at such a rate of velocity that small masses of air
                                                                                                                          could be made to move rocks and tear up large trees by the
                                                                                                                          roots, as is often done.
                                                                                                                            But the motive power of the whirlwind does not rest upon
                                                                                                                          a priori evidence alone, or upon the mere fact that its spin
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:30 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          ning motion is many times greater than its mere mechanical
                                                                                                                          motion of translation.  There is positive evidence that this
                                                                                                                          motive power is electricity. T'lis evidence consists in the
                                                                                                                          indications given out by the gold-leaf electrometer, when
                                                                                                                          actually carried into the whirlwind.    Some of these indica
                                                                                                                          tions, which were observed in the Great Basin of the Rocky
                                                                                                                          Mountains, in the years 1858-9, at latitude 400 15' north, lon
                                                                                                                          gitude 1120 12' west, we will now proceed to give.
                                                                                                                             The general form assumed by the whirlwinds observed
                                                                                                                          was that of a tube of dust, of greater or less diameter,
                                                                                                                          extending from the surface of the earth to a height of several
                                                                                                                          hundred feet. The interior of the tubes seemed to be dark
                                                                                                                          er than the exterior, which was owing, doubtless, to the
                                                                                                                          fact that the dust appeared to be thicker at their sides, and
                                                                                                                          hence whiter than at other points.      These   tubes were gen
                                                                                                                          erally perpendicular to the surface   of the earth, though one
                                                                                                                          was noticed that assumed a zigzag     direction ; and in another
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          instance, the tube, after mounting    vertically for a short dis
                                                                                                                          tance, then followed a horizontal     direction for a time, and
                                                                                                                          finally turned, and in the last part of its upward         course
                                                                                                                          became vertical   again.   At   times these     tubes   seemed   to
                                                                                                                                                          23

                                                                                                                          96         RECREATIONS      IN POPULAR              SCIENCE.           [Phelps.
                                                                                                                          flash up suddenly, reminding one of the movements of cor
                                                                                                                          uscation of the northern lights.
                                                                                                                            But one of the most remarkable features attending their
                                                                                                                          movements was the contention which they often exhibited
                                                                                                                          between upward and downward forces. Nodular rings of
                                                                                                                          dust would be seen, at times, ascending the tube, and evi
                                                                                                                          dently in opposition to some force acting against them from
                                                                                                                          above.   Particles of dust would be spun off from these rings
                                                                                                                          downward, but the upward motion would generally prevail.
                                                                                                                          Occasionally the eye would be arrested by a flax-like mass
                                                                                                                          of dust suspended for a moment in the air, as if it might
                                                                                                                          have been one of these nodular rings suddenly abandoned
                                                                                                                          by the vanishing of the tube on which it had mounted.
                                                                                                                            The following extracts from a journal will still further

                                                                                                                             " The whirlwinds    have been numerous   and exceedingly

                                                                                                                                6.    Weighing the Earth in a 6oal-pit.
                                                                                                                                'HE       determination   of   the mean density   of the earth   is
                                                                                                                           X     one of the most important as well as one of the most
                                                                                                                          interesting problems of physical astronomy.     The theory of
                                                                                                                          gravitation, combined with  our knowledge   of the movements
                                                                                                                          of the various bodies of the planetary system, enables us to
                                                                                                                          ascertain the masses of those bodies relatively to the earth's
                                                                                                                          mass ; but it would be impossible from such data alone to
                                                                                                                          arrive at any definite knowledge respecting their absolute
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:30 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          densities.  For instance, we know by the perturbations
                                                                                                                          which Jupiter exercises upon the movements of the other
                                                                                                                          planets of the system, that the quantity of matter which the
                                                                                                                          planet contains must amount to about three hundred and
                                                                                                                          forty times the quantity of matter contained in the earth ; but
                                                                                                                          this result does not inform us whether the planet is, bulk for
                                                                                                                          bulk, heavier or lighter than cork or lead, or any other
                                                                                                                          known substance. In order to ascertain this, we must know
                                                                                                                          beforehand       weight of the earth compared with the
                                                                                                                                            the
                                                                                                                          weight of an equal volume of some known substance, such
                                                                                                                          as water ; in other words, we must be acquainted with the
                                                                                                                          mean density of the earth relatively to the density of water.
                                                                                                                          It is well known that the first solution of this important
                                                                                                                          problem was obtained towards the close of the last century
                                                                                                                          by Dr. Maskelyne, from observations of the disturbing influ
                                                                                                                          ence exercised upon the direction of the plumb-line by the
                                                                                                                          attraction of the mountain of Schehallien, in Perthshire.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          The result deduced on that occasion indicated that the mean
                                                                                                                          density    of
                                                                                                                                      the earth was between four and five times the
                                                                                                                          density of water.   It would appear, from subsequent experi
                                                                                                                          ments of a different kind, that the mean density of the earth
                                                                                                                          is, in reality, somewhat higher than this ; but in all such
                                                                                                                                                                3°

                                                                                                                          T1mes.]   WEIGHING THE EARTH IN A COAL-PIT.
                                                                                                                          experiments the process is of so delicate a nature, consisting
                                                                                                                          in observations on the attraction of leaden spheres, that it
                                                                                                                          was felt highly desirable to verify the result by means of a
                                                                                                                          totally different solution of the problem.  This object has
                                                                                                                          been successfully achieved by Mr. Airy, the present astron
                                                                                                                          omer royal.     The method consisted in making a series of
                                                                                                                          observations on the rate at which the pendulum oscillates at
                                                                                                                          the top and at the bottom of a deep coal mine near South
                                                                                                                          Shields, termed Harton Colliery. At the top of the mine the
                                                                                                                          pendulum was acted upon by the attraction of the whole earth ;
                                                                                                                          but at the "bottom, the exterior shell of matter, whose thick
                                                                                                                          ness is equal to the depth of the mine, exercised no influence
                                                                                                                          whatever upon the oscillations of the pendulum.     Hence we
                                                                                                                          might be apt to infer that the pendulum would oscillate more
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:30 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          quickly at the top of the mine than at the bottom. But it is
                                                                                                                          to be borne in mind that at the bottom    of the mine the pen
                                                                                                                          dulum was nearer the centre of the earth (or, more strictly
                                                                                                                          speaking, nearer the great proportion of the earth's mass) than
                                                                                                                          at the top of the mine ; and the increase of attraction, arising
                                                                                                                          from this cause, may consequently be greater than the dimi
                                                                                                                          nution due to the smaller quantity of the attracting matter.
                                                                                                                          It may, therefore, happen that the pendulum would oscillate
                                                                                                                          more quickly at the bottom of the mine than at the top.
                                                                                                                          Now, this is precisely the result which Mr. Airy obtained
                                                                                                                          from his experiments with the pendulum at the top and bot
                                                                                                                          tom of the Harton Colliery. This mine is stated to be twelve
                                                                                                                          hundred and sixty feet deep.   By an extensive series of ob
                                                                                                                          servations, the astronomer royal found that, in twenty-four
                                                                                                                          hours, the seconds pendulum made two and a quarter more
                                                                                                                          vibrations at the bottom of the mine than it did at the top,
                                                                                                                          and consequently, that the force of gravity was increased at
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          the lower station by TSTff1i- part. By this means it is possi
                                                                                                                          ble to weigh the exterior shell of matter against the whole
                                                                                                                          earth ; and as the density of the shell (or rather the part
                                                                                                                          which is near the mine, and which alone exercises any sen
                                                                                                                          sible influence), relatively to any known substance, can be
                                                                                                                                                         31

                                                                                                                                    RECREATIONS IN POPULAR SCIENCE.
                                                                                                                          ascertained by observation, we are thus enabled to arrive at
                                                                                                                          a knowledge of the mean density of the earth.     By a rough
                                                                                                                          calculation, Mr. Airy has found that the density of the earth,
                                                                                                                          as deduced from these experiments, exceeds any value of
                                                                                                                          the same element which has hitherto been deduced, amount
                                                                                                                          ing to between six and seven times the density of water. It
                                                                                                                          would appear, therefore, to be about equal to the density of
                                                                                                                          cast iron.

                                                                                                                          128        RECREATIONS    IN POPULAR SCIENCE.          [Chase.
                                                                                                                          must be something in the climate which injures them."        I
                                                                                                                          believe that climate has nothing to do with dental decay.
                                                                                                                          The savages who inhabited the State of Missouri a hundred
                                                                                                                          years ago, or even fifty years since, had teeth perfectly
                                                                                                                          formed and of dense structure, and undecayed.      I have in

                                                                                                                          earth by myself, five years ago, from the bottom of a mound

                                                                                                                          always had the reputation of perfect dental structures. The
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:30 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          food and habits of these savages were simple and natural.

                                                                                                                          reverse and more like that of the whites.

                                                                                                                          had far better teeth than their descendants.
                                                                                                                            When I was a boy (1825), the profession of dentistry was
                                                                                                                          unknown in America ; there were not more than half a
                                                                                                                          dozen dentists in the United States. Toothache was not
                                                                                                                          common.      Many persons eighty years of age had never lost

                                                                                                                            We must look    to other influences than the climate, then,
                                                                                                                          for the degeneracy of the teeth. I  think these may be found
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          in the history of each individual who suffers from dental
                                                                                                                          decay.   The teeth are easily dissolved in weak acids ; so a
                                                                                                                          continuous acid condition of the mouth will produce decay.
                                                                                                                          Two thirds of the weight of a tooth is composed of lime, the
                                                                                                                          carbonate and phosphate ; the other third is an animal basis,
                                                                                                                          giving shape to the tooth. The lime salts give hardness.
                                                                                                                                                       24

                                                                                                                          Chase.]     THE DEGENERACY OF THE TEETH.                       129
                                                                                                                          To  produce good teeth, the blood must be well supplied with
                                                                                                                          these lime salts ; for it is out of the blood that all the tissues
                                                                                                                          of the body are formed. The blood, being the result of the
                                                                                                                          digestion of the food which has been eaten, must partake of
                                                                                                                          the character of that food alone.       Suppose food is used for
                                                                                                                          a long time which is deficient in these salts of lime ; then, of
                                                                                                                          course, the blood   will   be   lacking in those salts. When growth
                                                                                                                          is taking place, as it does from conception to the twenty-first
                                                                                                                          year, there is a great demand for lime salts, not only to pro
                                                                                                                          duce growth of the teeth, but to produce the bones also. A
                                                                                                                          definite amount of these salts are "used up" in the body
                                                                                                                          daily, and are cast out, as worthless, through the fasces, urine,
                                                                                                                          and perspiration.     Not only are lime salts daily used in the
                                                                                                                          teeth and bones, but in every tissue of the body. These facts
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:30 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          show the importance of intelligence in the selection of food.

                                                                                                                                             elaborated this subject, and gave tables of
                                                                                                                          analysis of various foods, with remarks on their relative value.

                                                                                                                          tain, are sufficiently supplied with these factors of dental nu
                                                                                                                          trition and growth.      Variety in diet is useful, not only in
                                                                                                                          stimulating the appetite, and promoting digestion, but in
                                                                                                                          therefore making more sure of a general average of nutri

                                                                                                                                  REAT   is the charm which the sea has at all times had
                                                                                                                          vJT     for man. Every one of us who has been brought up

Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:30 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                             What chains us most closely to the ocean and excites our
                                                                                                                          fancy, is its loneliness and immensity.
                                                                                                                             No stretch of land habitable by man is so unbroken on its
                                                                                                                          surface as not to present to the eye numerous resting-points ;
                                                                                                                          but over the surface of the sea the eye glides on unhindered,
                                                                                                                          like the waves which ruffle it ; and even the sharply defined
                                                                                                                          line    of the horizon we cannot acknowledge    as such, but in
                                                                                                                          imagination          on into immeasurable space.
                                                                                                                                          travel                                  But for
                                                                                                                          this reason,   — becausethe sea calls up in us the idea of the
                                                                                                                          endless, which we are not able to pursue, — we gladly turn
                                                                                                                          our eyes again to the land, its fixed forms, its green, familiar
                                                                                                                          slopes, and blue mountains.
                                                                                                                             In contrast with the land, the sea appears to us a waste.
                                                                                                                          When Homer calls it " the harvestless," he expresses an
                                                                                                                          idea which is forced upon every one of us.      From the ex
                                                                                                                          treme borders of the coast unapproachable bv the flood-wave
                                                                                                                          to the limit of eternal snow, there are few places on the land
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          which are not suited for the development of plant life ; and,

                                                                                                                          animal life is fostered. But over the sea we can sail for days
                                                                                                                          at a time without seeing a sign of life about us, excepting,
                                                                                                                          perhaps, the birds which follow the wake of the vessel.
                                                                                                                                                              I

                                                                                                                          138        RECREATIONS IN POPULAR SCIENCE.                  [Kny.

                                                                                                                          presents in especially favored spots.    This conviction is not
                                                                                                                          the result of recent inquiries ; it is expressed plainly in the
                                                                                                                          myths of the old civilizations, in which the sea is the original
                                                                                                                          seat   of life, the source of the visible creation.   The Greeks
                                                                                                                          worshipped in the mighty Oceanus the ancestor of all beings,
                                                                                                                          even of the gods, and peopled his kingdom with thousands

                                                                                                                             Besides the food-materials, two of the outward conditions

                                                                                                                              If  large mass of water becomes cooled off at its surface,
                                                                                                                                   a
                                                                                                                          the water which, through a loss of warmth, is rendered
                                                                                                                          specifically heavier, sinks below, and is replaced by warmer
                                                                                                                          and lighter water.    The lowest strata of water must there
                                                                                                                          fore be the coldest till the whole mass has acquired the tem
                                                                                                                          perature at which water possesses the greatest density.
                                                                                                                          With chemically pure water, this happens at 4.0S0 C. ; with
                                                                                                                          sea-water, at — 3-67° C. It is only below this temperature that
                                                                                                                          sea-water freezes.     It   is therefore conceivable   that near the
                                                                                                                          poles the whole mass of sea-water can fall to a temperature
                                                                                                                          below zero without congealing into ice. In the greater

                                                                                                                          is due, first of all, to the currents in the sea, which, like the
                                                                                                                                       10                    9

                                                                                                                                    RECREATIONS       IN POPULAR SCIENCE.                     CKny.
                                                                                                                          trade-winds in the atmosphere, carry towards the poles the
                                                                                                                          water warmed by the rays of the tropical sun and thereby
                                                                                                                          rendered lighter, and replace it by cold under-currents from
                                                                                                                          the poles.   In this way, under all latitudes, conditions are
