                                                                                                                          common in the lower animals, gives the zoologist a certain
                                                                                                                          claim upon them, as does also the spontaneous locomotion
                                                                                                                          of certain species. The Bacillariaceae even belong to those
                                                                                                                          organisms which, like the slime fungi (Myromycetae), unite
                                                                                                                          in themselves both the animal and plant nature, and it is to
                                                                                                                          a certain degree left to the choice as to which of the two
                                                                                                                          prganic kingdoms they shall be assigned. Yet the natural
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          affinities of the Bacillariaceae speak strongly in favor of their
                                                                                                                          vegetable nature, and we cannot decide to yield the right of
                                                                                                                          possession which the botanist has over this beautiful group
                                                                                                                          of    one-celled organisms.
                                                                                                                               The Bacillariaceae appear, in numerous species, not only
                                                                                                                                                         15

                                                                                                                                        RECREATIONS       IN POPULAR SCIENCE.               [Khy.
                                                                                                                               in the sea, but also in fresh and in waste water. Their dif
                                                                                                                               fusion, is almost unlimited, as well in a vertical direction as
                                                                                                                               in a horizontal ; they inhabit the torrent of the high Alps,
                                                                                                                               and are also to be met with in the greatest sea-depths. The
                                                                                                                               one-celled individuals either live isolated, and are then fre
                                                                                                                           quently endowed        with the power of spontaneous locomo
                                                                                                                           tion, but more rarely are fastened to larger sea-plants ; or
                                                                                                                           they are united in colonies or companies.      It may happen
                                                                                                                           that the cells are united so as to form lines in the direction
                                                                                                                           in which they increase by repeated bisections; or numbers
                                                                                                                           of them settle upon jelly cushions ; or they are borne on
                                                                                                                           gelatinous branched threads, or stems, which are fastened
                                                                                                                           upon stones on the sea-bottom, upon animals, or upon larger
                                                                                                                           sea-plants ; or they are embedded in great numbers in a gelat
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:30 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                           inous case, which itself again assumes different forms, grows
                                                                                                                           in length, and can branch.
                                                                                                                              The high favor in which the Bacillariaceae stand with all
                                                                                                                          friends of microscopic investigation is due to the variety and
                                                                                                                          beauty of their forms, and to the artistic sculpturing of their
                                                                                                                          membranes.     In both respects, they stand unequalled in the
                                                                                                                          plant kingdom.     On the outer surface of the cells are
                                                                                                                          coarser or finer flutes, which mostly run in great numbers
                                                                                                                          parallel to one another, and, at the same time, others fre
                                                                                                                          quently cross them at right or acute angles ; or the mem
                                                                                                                          brane is marked by knob-like elevations or small pock-like
                                                                                                                          pits. He who has not convinced himself with his own eyes
                                                                                                                          will scarcely believe what great  success in artistic forms and
                                                                                                                          groupings  Nature   has attained with  such small means. The
                                                                                                                          known species are already counted by the thousands, and
                                                                                                                          yet every one possesses a peculiar form, or bears upon its
                                                                                                                          membrane its special mark wholly different from any other.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                            In other respects, also, the membrane in the Bacillariaceae
                                                                                                                          is   peculiarly constructed.   It   does not, as is the case in   all
                                                                                                                          other one-celled plants and with all plant-cells united into a
                                                                                                                          web, surround the protoplasm as a closed cell, but it consists
                                                                                                                          of two separate parts, the larger of which tightly closes over
                                                                                                                                                              16

                                                                                                                           K.NY.]            PLANT LIFE IN THE SEA.                    153
                                                                                                                           the smaller  like the cover of a bandbox.   In the process of
                                                                                                                           growth, which always takes place in a line perpendicular to
                                                                                                                           the direction of the division-wall that appears later, the two
                                                                                                                           parts shove themselves further and further from one another,
                                                                                                                           until, after the formation of two new membranes encased in
                                                                                                                           a   similar way to the old ones, the previously existing union
                                                                                                                           is dissolved.
                                                                                                                             Whilst the membranes of most plant-cells are perishable,
                                                                                                                          and, after the death of their protoplasm, in a short time fall
                                                                                                                          into decay, the ornamental cases of the Bacillariaceae cells
                                                                                                                          remain, after the death of the plant, apparently unchanged.
                                                                                                                          But they are not only able to offer opposition to the slow
                                                                                                                          effect of decay, but also to the attack of the strongest sul
                                                                                                                          phuric or nitric acid and to a continuous white heat. This
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:30 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          quality they owe to the fact that they contain a large quantity
                                                                                                                          of silex. Cell-material and silex are so closely intermingled
                                                                                                                          in every part of the membrane, however small, that the
                                                                                                                          structure remains perfect, though one or another constituent
                                                                                                                          may be removed.        The cell-material is best destroyed by
                                                                                                                          heat, after which a transparent skeleton of silica remains ;
                                                                                                                          the silex is easily drawn out by means of fluoric acid without
                                                                                                                          touching the cell-material.
                                                                                                                             After what has just been said, it is very easy to conceive
                                                                                                                           that at the bottom of those waters in which Bacillariaceae
                                                                                                                          live in great numbers, the flinty skeletons of the membranes
                                                                                                                          of all the past generations must be heaped up. The slime
                                                                                                                          of fresh-water lakes and of our German North-Sea coast
                                                                                                                          offers sufficient proof of this. If, by means of currents,
                                                                                                                          great masses of flinty shells are collected in especially favora
                                                                                                                          ble spots, and then bound together by a limy or silicious
                                                                                                                          cement withdrawn from the water, in this way mighty
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          masses of rock can arise in the course of a thousand years.
                                                                                                                          In Europe, the best-known example of this kind is the Berlin
                                                                                                                          polishing-stone ; in America, the diatomaceous earth, five
                                                                                                                          hundred feet thick, in Oregon.          Even the flint-stones,
                                                                                                                          which, in the form of roundish knobs, are lodged in
                                                                                                                                                         »7

                                                                                                                                       RECREATIONS IN POPULAR SCIENCE.                 [Kwv.

                                                                                                                          grades of organic life, the usual mode of increase is by bipar-
                                                                                                                          tition. There is always a growth of the cell perpendicularly
                                                                                                                          to the     direction   of division-wall, that appears later.
                                                                                                                                                       the
                                                                                                                          When the daughter-cells have individualized themselves, the
                                                                                                                          same process is completed in them.       Since the successive

                                                                                                                          order were not disturbed, in the case of the species which
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:30 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          live isolated, by the breaking of the line into single cells ;
                                                                                                                          and, in the case of most of those forming colonies, by a se

                                                                                                                             In the .separation, each of the two daughter-cells receives

                                                                                                                          the inside of the old one that overlaps.  It follows from this
                                                                                                                          that one of the two daughter-cells only possesses the full size
                                                                                                                          of the mother-cell ; the other, on the contrary, is shorter by
                                                                                                                          double the thickness        of              The descendants of
                                                                                                                                                           the membrane.
                                                                                                                          a cell, therefore, will show greater differences in their length,

                                                                                                                          orders, those of the Confe1-vaceae, the Fucoideae, and the
                                                                                                                          Florideae. They form the chief mass of sea vegetation, and,
                                                                                                                          more than any other plants, give it its character.
                                                                                                                            Besides the more important signs of difference dependent
                                                                                                                          upon their development, they vary in color.
                                                                                                                            The Confervaceae are almost entirely of a pure, bright
                                                                                                                          grass-green color. Combined with the dark olive-green or
                                                                                                                          brown Fucoideae, they cover the shore to a slight depth ;
                                                                                                                          among the latter, many are left by the ebb-tide wholly bare.
                                                                                                                          The Florideae, on the contrary, whose color increases from
                                                                                                                          a brownish-red and violet to the most brilliant purple, abound
                                                                                                                          at the lowest limit of the sea-flora ; although not a few
                                                                                                                          species, some widely diffused and very numerous, associate
                                                                                                                          themselves with the green and brown Algae just below the
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:30 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          surface of the sea.
                                                                                                                             The green Confervaceae are the proletarians among the sea
                                                                                                                          Algae. Prominent neither from their outline, nor from the
                                                                                                                          richness and beauty of their forms, they have, besides the
                                                                                                                          freshness of their coloring, scarcely anything outwardly at
                                                                                                                          tractive.  Their construction, also, in comparison with the
                                                                                                                          groups that follow, shows but little complication.          The
                                                                                                                          Chaetomorphae   are branchless threads, built up out of a single
                                                                                                                          row of cells, which, under the assaults of the waves, fre
                                                                                                                          quently weave themselves into snarled twists. In the species
                                                                                                                          Cladophora, which has very varied forms, the limb-cells of the
                                                                                                                          stem send out branches in one or two opposite directions,
                                                                                                                          which, in their turn, are capable of 'ramification in the same
                                                                                                                          way.    Among the Ulvaceae we meet with forms which
                                                                                                                          present one layer of cells, and are of irregular outline (Mo-
                                                                                                                           nostroma) ; others in which the layer is double (Phycoseris).
                                                                                                                          Joined with these are hollow, irregularly brenched cell-
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          bodies with a walling of one layer, the average breadth of
                                                                                                                          which varies from that of a fine thread to many inches (En-
                                                                                                                          teromorpha).

                                                                                                                          vaceae wholly by means of zoospores, which arise from a

                                                                                                                          division of the protoplasm into a smaller or larger number

                                                                                                                          a side opening.    Their form is similar to that of the zoo
                                                                                                                          spores of the Bryopsis (Fig. I, E). Propagation is effected
                                                                                                                          by two or four delicate scintillating threads, which spring
                                                                                                                          from the colorless anterior end.    On the side, at a slight
                                                                                                                          distance from the end, is a red spot, which, from incorrect

                                                                                                                          end with its thread-like appendages being, for the most part,
                                                                                                                          ahead, — it fastens itself by means of these threads upon a

                                                                                                                          divisions at the upper end, into a new plant.      Besides these
                                                                                                                          zoospores which thus increase the species in an ungenerative
                                                                                                                          way, small spores of a similar form are produced, which,
                                                                                                                          apparently, are only capable of further development after
                                                                                                                          uniting together by pairs. In the fresh-water Confervaceae
                                                                                                                          .(Uloth'rix zonata), a genital act of this simple kind has been
                                                                                                                          proved ; an accurate observation of its existence among the
                                                                                                                          marine species is yet wanting.
                                                                                                                            The olive-green and brown Algae, which we class to
                                                                                                                          gether in the order of the Fucoideae, play the most impor
                                                                                                                          tant part among the vegetable inhabitants of the sea, on ac
                                                                                                                          count of the great number    of   the   individuals and the masses
                                                                                                                          in which they appear.
                                                                                                                             In the dimensions which single ones attain, they stand
                                                                                                                          unequalled among the Algae, perhaps even among plants of
                                                                                                                          all kinds ; in variety of outward and inward structure, the
                                                                                                                          Florideae alone are able to vie with them.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                             The chief mass of all Fucoideae is divided into two great
                                                                                                                          families, to which a large number of the smaller Algae, less
                                                                                                                          perfectly known in their mode of development, seem to
                                                                                                                          incline.   They bear the names of the Phaeosporeae and the
                                                                                                                          Fucaceae.    The difference between them lies especially in
                                                                                                                                                            26

                                                                                                                          Ksy.]                PLANT LIFE IN THE SEA.                163
                                                                                                                          their mode of propagation.   Among the Phaeosporeae, there
                                                                                                                          have been found as yet only small zo6spores of peculiar for
                                                                                                                          mation different from those of the green Algae. They are
                                                                                                                          oval or top-shaped, pointed towards the colorless fore-end.
                                                                                                                          From a red spot on the side, which contrasts strongly with
                                                                                                                          the brown coloring of the back part, spring two delicate
                                                                                                                          threads, the longer    of which is during locomotion directed
                                                                                                                          forward, while the shorter is dragged behind. Among the
                                                                                                                          majority of the well-known species, these zoospores are
                                                                                                                          produced in two kinds of mother-cells.     Either they arise
                                                                                                                          in large numbers in isolated cells of globular or oval form
                                                                                                                          and of proportionally large circumference ; or they are
                                                                                                                          formed singly ; — in many kinds also in small numbers — in
                                                                                                                          little cells, many of which are ranged upon one another into
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:30 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          slightly branched threads ; or they are grouped otherwise.
                                                                                                                          Both kinds of fruit-forms may appear at the same time on
                                                                                                                          the same plant   they may belong to different individuals ; or
                                                                                                                                           ;
                                                                                                                          they may separate from the same individual at successive
                                                                                                                          stages of development, which latter seems to be most fre
                                                                                                                          quently the case.   Since the zoospores issuing from those
                                                                                                                          last described are a little larger than those of the former
                                                                                                                          kinds, the supposition is very natural that different parts
                                                                                                                          may be assigned to the two in germination ; that the one
                                                                                                                          may be able to produce a new plant directly, and the others
                                                                                                                          only after previous pairing.
                                                                                                                            In view of the close harmony which exists within the
                                                                                                                          great family of the Phaosporeae in the development of their
                                                                                                                          propagating cells, the numerous gradations in the structure of
                                                                                                                          their vegetating parts gain a double interest. Here is exhib
                                                                                                                          ited how much Nature, within a narrow circle of relation
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          ships, is able to accomplish by changing and perfecting a
                                                                                                                          simple type. The lowest rank is held by Ectocarpus with
                                                                                                                          several closely related species, which, like the Confervaceae,
                                                                                                                          is distinguished by threads branched in various ways.       In
                                                                                                                          the higher forms, the branching is more regular, and the
                                                                                                                          threads seem to form woven tissues ; since their branchlets
                                                                                                                                                          27

                                                                                                                          164      RECREATIONS IN POPULAR SCIENCE.                   [Kny.
                                                                                                                          lie close beside one another, and are cemented together, or
                                                                                                                          they twine   into one another after the mode      of parasites.
                                                                                                                          Examples of this kind are offered by the species Mesogkea
                                                                                                                          with its relations, found in the Mediterranean and in the At
                                                                                                                          lantic Ocean, and distinguished by its jelly-like consistency.
                                                                                                                          The group of the Sphacelareae presents a more perfect web-
                                                                                                                          formation.    The large cell at the top of the main stem, while
                                                                                                                          it lengthens continually, separates cells in the direction of
                                                                                                                          the base repeatedly by cross walls, which cells are added to
                                                                                                                          the stem as new links, and, by further divisions lengthwise
                                                                                                                          and crosswise of their growth, they add also to the circumfer
                                                                                                                          ence.   These divisions in the higher forms of the group fol
                                                                                                                          low fixed rules. Every cell produced by the divisions of the
                                                                                                                          stem-members gives to the stem definite portions of its texture,
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:30 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          and certain cells are predestined, from the moment of their

                                                                                                                          moment, by the position of the cells and by the interior
                                                                                                                          structure, is the way paved for the architectural proportions
                                                                                                                          which we admire in the grown plant.
                                                                                                                            If  the previously mentioned forms of the Phaeosporeae
                                                                                                                          rise to medium or only small proportions, yet we see the
                                                                                                                          Laminariaceae grown into Algae many feet long.          Every

                                                                                                                          rocks below the usual ebb-tide, they form extensive subma
                                                                                                                          rine meadows around the island, and, after storms, are thrown
                                                                                                                          up in great quantities by the breakers.

                                                                                                                          brane ; soon after, the first separation-walls appear within it
                                                                                                                          (Fig. 2, G) ; the part towards the base sends out first a root
                                                                                                                          like hair, later several, which help the young germinating
                                                                                                                          plant to fasten itself (Fig. 2, H), and it grows, with constant
                                                                                                                          increase of cells, into the fully developed plant.
                                                                                                                             If it is really, as we believe, the spermatozoids which excite
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:30 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          the egg-cells to further development, then by the exclusion
                                                                                                                          of them germination must be prevented. By experiment,
                                                                                                                          this supposition has been perfectly confirmed.        If
                                                                                                                                                                              a large
                                                                                                                          number of egg-cells are put alone by themselves in sea-
                                                                                                                          water under circumstances otherwise wholly favorable, they
                                                                                                                          will for   some  days remain unchanged, but, at length, will
                                                                                                                          decay. In what way the spermatozoids accomplish fecun
                                                                                                                          dation has not yet, in the Fucus vesiculosus, been ascer
                                                                                                                          tained with perfect certainty ; but it is evident, from analogy
                                                                                                                          with other Algae, that they penetrate into the egg-cell and
                                                                                                                          blend directly with its substance.
                                                                                                                             In spite of the great advance which the Fucaceae show,
                                                                                                                          in structure and mode of propagation,         over   the groups
                                                                                                                          spoken of earlier, yet they by no means present the highest
                                                                                                                          grade of development among the sea Algae.    The first rank
                                                                                                                          belongs to the Florideae. The bright coloring which most
                                                                                                                          of them exhibit, and which varies, in all imaginable shades,
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          from a muddy violet to a brilliant purple, and the mode of

                                                                                                                          ent interest and admiration.    Unfortunately it is for the most
                                                                                                                          part more difficult to obtain them in their native places than
                                                                                                                                                       35

                                                                                                                                   RECREATIONS         IN POPULAR SCIENCE.             [Knv.
                                                                                                                          it is to get other plant inhabitants of the sea. They live
                                                                                                                          mostly in depths which are not left entirely bare by the
                                                                                                                          ebbing sea, even at the time of the full and the new moon ;
                                                                                                                          yet they are found, after heavy storms, on specially favored
                                                                                                                          points of the coast, thrown up in great numbers with other

                                                                                                                             The gracefulness of their forms not only makes the Flo-
                                                                                                                          rideae favorites with the collector ; the perfect conformity to

                                                                                                                          which are built up out of rows of cells, the mode of growth

                                                                                                                          with a clearness scarcely to be found in any other division
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:30 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          of the Algae.   Higher up we meet with forms in which the
                                                                                                                          threads range themselves into surfaces and into bodies with
                                                                                                                          a contour such as to characterize them.   In this way arise

                                                                                                                          the forked expanse of the Rhodymenia and Chondrus species,
                                                                                                                          the round or flat stems   of the Gracilariae, the calcined stalks
                                                                                                                          of the Corallineae.    In most cases, the union of the cells,
                                                                                                                          side to side, on the growing summit of the plant, is so inti
                                                                                                                          mate, that it needs very close investigation to become certain
                                                                                                                          concerning the mode of formation of the texture. In the

                                                                                                                          becomes generally more distinct.     It is not a rare thing for

                                                                                                                          with them in different directions.   It even sometimes hap
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          pens that younger threads bore into the older ones, and fill
                                                                                                                                                                         '
                                                                                                                          up the cells of which they are composed.     All these means
                                                                                                                          together  serve to give the older parts of the  plant greater
                                                                                                                          firmness, and to make it more able to withstand the pressure

                                                                                                                            Here at the close, as we look back upon the picture of the
                                                                                                                          vegetation of the sea which we have unrolled, it seems, in
                                                                                                                          comparison with what Nature has presented to us, very
                                                                                                                          meagre and incomplete.    Out of the varied treasure of living
                                                                                                                          forms we have seized hold of some few, in order to give to
                                                                                                                          what we present retentive points, and yet these can only be
                                                                                                                          rightly understood in connection with all the rest of the plant
                                                                                                                          inhabitants of the sea. And this also is not sufficient. We
                                                                                                                          must not forget that vegetation as a whole, in the depths of
                                                                                                                          the sea as well as upon the mainland, is affected by the
                                                                                                                          animal world    that both kingdoms, in those things needful
                                                                                                                                           ;
                                                                                                                          to life, are mutually adapted to one another ; that, conse
                                                                                                                          quently, a perfect understanding of plant-life is not obtained
                                                                                                                          without a knowledge of animal life.
                                                                                                                             Though it is only a small portion of the sea flora which               I
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google

                                                                                                                          only a part and, as it were, the key-stone of a series of de

                                                                                                                          all the numerous species and generations of individuals

                                                                                                                          the Algae were not, for the most part, of such tender consist
                                                                                                                          ency, and, therefore, less adapted than almost all other

                                                                                                                                         From the Quarterly   Journal of   Science.
                                                                                                                                          has been   done to reduce the chances       of ship
                                                                                                                          MUCH
                                                                                                                             wreck upon         our coast, always so difficult of naviga
                                                                                                                          tion, and yet very little is generally known of the progress in
                                                                                                                          the application of science to indicate to the mariner his
                                                                                                                          proximity to danger. There are two ways of assisting sea
                                                                                                                          men in their passage on a coast-line, — by the lighthouse, of
                                                                                                                          use by day and night ; and by the buoy or beacon, by use by
                                                                                                                          day alone. But often, and indeed in the majority of cases,
                                                                                                                          the rock or projecting spit is too small, and not sufficiently
                                                                                                                          important to allow of the erection of a lighthouse, with the
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:31 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          necessary expensive apparatus and shelter for the keepers.
                                                                                                                          Some other expedient must then be found, and recourse i§
                                                                                                                          had to the mooring of a buoy, or the erection of a light iron
                                                                                                                          work beacon. It is evident that the value of these substi
                                                                                                                          tutes is but small, as they are visible by day only, and that
                                                                                                                          the advantages to'be derived from their illumination are all
                                                                                                                          important ; for it must be borne in mind that a vessel when in
                                                                                                                          mid-ocean is perfectly safe, compared with her position whea
                                                                                                                          nearing the coast.
                                                                                                                            The sources of illumination for beacons and buoys, Mr.
                                                                                                                          Thomas Stevenson, C. E., in his recently published work on
                                                                                                                          Lighthouse Illumination, considers the following : —
                                                                                                                             1st. The adoption of apparent or borrowed lights.
                                                                                                                             2d. The use of dipping lights for indicating the position
                                                                                                                          of shoals, by depressing the lamp and apparatus, so as to
                                                                                                                          cover with the light the ground that is dangerous.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                             3d. The construction either of voltaic, magnetic, or fric-
                                                                                                                          tional electricity, or that produced by the efflux of steam,
                                                                                                                          through wires, submarine, or, where practicable, suspended
                                                                                                                          in the air, so as to produce a spark either with or without
                                                                                                                          vacuum tubes, or by means of an electro-magnet and the
                                                                                                                          deflagration    of mercury.
                                                                                                                                                          46

                                                                                                                                                                '
                                                                                                                                 ILLUMINATION OF BEACONS AND BUOYS.                   183
                                                                                                                            4th. The conduction of gas from the shore in submarine
                                                                                                                          pipes.
                                                                                                                            5th. Self-acting electrical apparatus produced by the action
                                                                                                                          of sea-water or otherwise, at the beacon itself, so as to re
                                                                                                                          quire no connection with the shore.
                                                                                                                            This last method was suggested by Mr. Stevenson in
                                                                                                                          1866, and it is worthy of note that Mn A. Bain, in 1848,
                                                                                                                          produced and maintained a steady light, off Brighton, by the
                                                                                                                          use of sea-water as the exciting fluid of the galvanic ar
                                                                                                                          rangement.
                                                                                                                            The use of apparent or borrowed light is now, from its
                                                                                                                          simplicity, almost generally known. It consists of a certain
                                                                                                                          combination of prisms, contained in a lantern erected on a
                                                                                                                          sunken rock, for producing the divergence of parallel rays
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:31 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          emitted by a distant lamp placed on the shore.         Thus the
                                                                                                                          light seen by the seaman is merely a reflection of that on
                                                                                                                          shore, the parallel rays of the shore light being indistinguish
                                                                                                                          able at the distance from which the apparent or reflective
                                                                                                                          light is seen.
                                                                                                                             The third method of illumination, not as yet fully devel
                                                                                                                          oped, is, however, of paramount importance as providing
                                                                                                                          light for those situations where the apparent light is inap
                                                                                                                          plicable.
                                                                                                                            Faraday's discovery of the magneto-electric spark was first
                                                                                                                          adapted to lighthouse illumination by Professor Holmes, and
                                                                                                                          employed by the Trinity House in 1858.         In 1862, this
                                                                                                                          apparatus was placed at Dungeness, and here it has con
                                                                                                                          tinued to give out its light nightly, having been extinguished
                                                                                                                          only on one occasion, and then but for four or five minutes.
                                                                                                                          This machine consists of a number of powerful magnets
                                                                                                                          fixed into an octagonal frame. Bobbins or rods of soft iron,
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          around which are coiled helices of silk-covered copper wire,
                                                                                                                          are caused to rotate before the poles of the magnets, the
                                                                                                                          result of this rotation manifesting itself as powerful electric
                                                                                                                          currents in alternate directions. These currents, brought to
                                                                                                                          one direction by means of a commutator, are conveyed from
                                                                                                                          the machinery room to two carbon points fixed in the lantern
                                                                                                                                                        47

                                                                                                                          184
                                                                                                                                    RECREATIONS     IN POPULAR SCIENCE.
                                                                                                                          of the lighthouse.   The carbons being raised to incandes
                                                                                                                          cence, are gradually consumed, and this consumption is the
                                                                                                                          weak point of the system, necessitating a delicate automatic
                                                                                                                          arrangement to maintain    a constant distance between the
                                                                                                                          points.
                                                                                                                            The remaining source of illumination is by gas. In 1853,
                                                                                                                          Admiral Sheringham illuminated a buoy in this manner off
                                                                                                                          Portsmouth.  The gas was conveyed as far as possible in
                                                                                                                          iron pipes, then continued through a gutta-percha tube to
                                                                                                                          the beacon.   The gas was lighted by means of a platinum
                                                                                                                          wire, rendered incandescent by the passage of a voltaic cur
                                                                                                                          rent from a small battery on shore.   The results, however,
                                                                                                                          were not published until quite lately.
                                                                                                                             A beacon on the Clyde, near Port Glasgow, was, in 1861,
                                                                                                                          lighted with gas, and has since been maintained. This bea
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:31 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          con is three hundred feet from shore, and the supply of gas
                                                                                                                          is regulated in a very ingenious manner.    A float is so ar
                                                                                                                          ranged in the principal burner that a certain pressure is
                                                                                                                          requisite to admit of the passage of the gas ; consequently,
                                                                                                                          when the gas is shut off from the main each morning, the
                                                                                                                          light would be completely extinguished each morning were
                                                                                                                          it not for a small burner that, being fed from a gas-holder of
                                                                                                                          about ten cubic feet capacity, situate in the body of the
                                                                                                                          buoy, remains alight all day. Again, each night as the
                                                                                                                          pressure increases, the float closing the supply tube to the
                                                                                                                          principal burner rises, and the beacon is fully illuminated.
                                                                                                                             The illumination of Arnish Point by the apparent light for

                                                                                                                              If   we analyze the process by which the ear distinguishes
                                                                                                                          a simple sound, we find that a tone results from the alternate
                                                                                                                          expansion and contraction of an elastic medium.        If this
                                                                                                                          process takes place in the medium in which the ear is .situ
                                                                                                                          ated,"namely, the atmosphere, then at each recurring conden
                                                                                                                          sation the elastic membrane, or tympanum, will be pressed
                                                                                                                          inward, and these vibrations will be transmitted from the
                                                                                                                          tympanum to the auricular nerves in the interior parts of the
                                                                                                                          ear, by means of a mechanical apparatus of wonderful deli
                                                                                                                          cacy and precision of action, consisting of a series of bones
                                                                                                                          termed respectively the hammer, anvil, and stirrup.    In the
                                                                                                                          process of reproducing tone by electro-magnetism, an artificial
                                                                                                                          imitation of ihe mechanism of the human ear is employed,
                                                                                                                          consisting of a stretched membrane, or diaphragm, corre
