                                                                                                                          sponding to the tympanum, which, by its vibrations, gen
                                                                                                                          erates and controls an electric circuit extended to a distant
                                                                                                                          station by a metallic conductor.
                                                                                                                              The greater the degree of condensation or contraction          of
                                                                                                                          the elastic medium in a given time, the greater is the extent
                                                                                                                          of the movement of the tympanum, and consequently of the
                                                                                                                          mechanism which acts upon the nerves. Hence it follows
                                                                                                                          that the function of the human ear is the mechanical trans
                                                                                                                          mission to the auditory nerves of each expansion and contrac
                                                                                                                          tion which occurs in the surrounding medium, while that of
                                                                                                                          the nerves is to convey to the brain the sensations thus pro
                                                                                                                          duced. A series of vibrations, a definite number of which
                                                                                                                          are produced in a given, time, and of which we thus become
                                                                                                                          cognizant, is called a tone.

                                                                                                                          ing a purely mechanical one, may be rendered much more
                                                                                                                          easy of comprehension by graphic delineation.         If, for ex

                                                                                                                             A  simple musical tone results from a continuous, rapid,
                                                                                                                          and uniformly recurring series of vibrations, providing the
                                                                                                                          number of complete vibrations per second falls within cer
                                                                                                                          tain limits. If, for example, the vibrations number less than

                                                                                                                          heard instead of a tone, while, if their number exceeds forty-

Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:31 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                             The ear distinguishes three distinct qualities in sound :
                                                                                                                             1. The tone, or pitch, by virtue of which sounds are high
                                                                                                                          or low, and which depends upon the rapidity of the vibratory
                                                                                                                          movement. The more rapid the vibrations, the more acute
                                                                                                                          will be the sound.
                                                                                                                             2. The intensity, by virtue of which sounds are loud or
                                                                                                                          soft, and  which depends upon the extent of the vibrations.
                                                                                                                             3. The quality, by which we are able to distinguish a note
                                                                                                                          sounded, for example, upon a violin, from the same note
                                                                                                                          when sounded upon a flute.          By a remarkable series of ex
                                                                                                                          perimental investigations, Helmholtz succeeded in demon
                                                                                                                          strating that the different qualities of sounds depend altogether
                                                                                                                          upon the number and intensity of the over-tones which ac
                                                                                                                          company the primary tones of those sounds. The different
                                                                                                                          characteristics of sound may be graphically represented, and
                                                                                                                          the phenomena thus rendered more easy of comprehension.

                                                                                                                                             PROF.   DOLBEAR'S    TELEPHONE.
                                                                                                                            During the autumn of 1876, Prof. A. E. Dolbear, of Tufts'
                                                                                                                          College (who claims to have been the first to substitute the
                                                                                                                          permanent magnet for the electro-magnet in the telephone),
                                                                                                                          observing that the actual function of the battery current with
                                                                                                                          which the line was charged in Bell's method, had simply
                                                                                                                          the effect of polarizing the soft iron cores of      the transmitting
                                                                                                                          and receiving instruments, or of converting          them into per
                                                                                                                          manent magnets, and that the mere passage            of the constant
                                                                                                                          voltaic current over the line had nothing to         do with the re
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          sult, conceived the idea of adopting the permanent magnet
                                                                                                                          in place of the battery or electro-magnet previously em
                                                                                                                          ployed.   Another important improvement which he made
                                                                                                                          consisted in using the same instrument for both sending and
                                                                                                                          receiving, instead of employing instruments of different con
                                                                                                                                                            15

                                                                                                                                       RECREATIONS           IN POPULAR SCIENCE.    [Garb1t.
                                                                                                                          struct ion   as   heretofore   by which changes the articulating
                                                                                                                                                         ;
                                                                                                                          properties of the        telephone were greatly improved      and
                                                                                                                          strengthened.
                                                                                                                             It consists of an ordinary, permanent bar magnet, NS; a sin
                                                                                                                          gle helix, H, of insulated copper wire, placed upon one end of
                                                                                                                          the magnet ; and a metallic diaphragm, D, consisting of a disc
                                                                                                                          of thin sheet-iron two and a quarter inches in diameter and one-
                                                                                                                          fiftieth of an inch thick, forming an armature to the magnet,
                                                                                                                          N S. The vibratory motions of the air produced by the voice,
                                                                                                                          or other cause, are directed toward, and concentrated upon,
                                                                                                                          the diaphragm,        D, by means of mouthpiece, T. It will
                                                                                                                                                                    a
                                                                                                                          thus be seen that when vibrations are communicated to the
                                                                                                                          air in front of the mouthpiece, the impact of the waves of
                                                                                                                          air against the elastic diaphragm will cause a corresponding
                                                                                                                          movement of the h1tter.    This, in turn, by reacting upon the
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:31 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          magnet, disturbs the normal magnetic condition of the bar,
                                                                                                                          and since any change of magnetism in this tends to generate
                                                                                                                          electrical currents in the surrounding helix, the circuit in
                                                                                                                          which the helix may be placed will be traversed by a series
                                                                                                                          of electrical pulsations or currents. Moreover, as these cur
                                                                                                                          rents continue to be generated so long as the motion of the
                                                                                                                          diaphragm continues, and as they increase and decrease in
                                                                                                                          strength with the amplitude of its vibrations, thus varying
                                                                                                                          with the variations of its amplitude, it is evident that they
                                                                                                                          virtually possess all the physical characteristics of the agent
                                                                                                                          acting upon the transmitting diaphragm.     Consequently, by
                                                                                                                          their electro-magnetic action upon the magnet of an appa
                                                                                                                          ratus identical with the one above described and placed at a
                                                                                                                          distance in the same circuit, they will cause its diaphragm
                                                                                                                          to vibrate in the same manner as that of the transmitting
                                                                                                                          apparatus.

                                                                                                                             Mr. Thomas A. Ed1son, of Menlo Park, New Jersey,
                                                                                                                          though the last on the list, has, in his Carbon Telephone,
                                                                                                                          introduced     complete novelty.
                                                                                                                                           a                 Mr. Edison had discovered
                                                                                                                          that certain kinds of carbon are enormously susceptible to
                                                                                                                          changes in conductivity upon being subjected to different
                                                                                                                          pressures, and that the ratios of those changes, moreover,
                                                                                                                          corresponded exactly with the pressure. He conceived the
                                                                                                                          idea of utilizing this property to transmit sound by the press
                                                                                                                          ure of these sound-waves, so that these differences should
                                                                                                                          cause corresponding changes in the electrical status of a tel
                                                                                                                          egraph wire. A button of sensitive carbon is placed between
                                                                                                                          two pieces of platinum.   The under piece of metal is attached
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          to the telegraph wire ; the upper piece is very thin, and is to
                                                                                                                          receive the pressure of the sound-waves.    That is communi
                                                                                                                          cated (through some intermediate substances) from the cen
                                                                                                                          tre of a receiving disc, such as is inseparable from every
                                                                                                                          form of telephone. Talking to the disc causes it to vibrate,
                                                                                                                                                        17

                                                                                                                          Z02      RECREATIONS. IN POPULAR SCIENCE.                   [Garb1t.
                                                                                                                          and thus to produce a difference of pressure on the carbon
                                                                                                                          button.  Finally, a two-cell battery is put into operation,
                                                                                                                          with one of its wires attached to the upper, and the other to
                                                                                                                          the lower piece of platinum, the circuit being closed by trans
                                                                                                                          mission through the carbon button between the platinum
                                                                                                                          plates. The transmission is less or more impeded accord
                                                                                                                          ing to the pressure which the sound-waves exert upon the
                                                                                                                          carbon button, and the telegraph wire communicates these

                                                                                                                            Up       to the present time, the   popular impression concerning
                                                                                                                          the telephone has been that the                sound was, in some way or
                                                                                                                          other, conveyed over the wire         but it will be obvious to

                                                                                                                          every reader of these pages that such is very far from being
                                                                                                                          the case.   The fact is, that it is one of the most beautiful and
                                                                                                                          striking examples which nature affords us of the convertibil
                                                                                                                          ity of forces from one form to another. There is first the
                                                                                                                          initial vibratory mechanical motion of the air, which is im
                                                                                                                          parted to the membrane carrying the iron.      This motion is
                                                                                                                          converted into electricity in the coil of wire surrounding the
                                                                                                                          electro-magnet, and at the receiving end is first effective as
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:31 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          magnetism; which is again converted into vibratory motion
                                                                                                                          of the iron armature, which motion is imparted to the air,
                                                                                                                          and so becomes again a sound-wave in air like the original
                                                                                                                          one.
                                                                                                                            During the passage of this brief notice through the press,
                                                                                                                          Prof. Thomas A. Edison, the inventor of the Carbon Tele
                                                                                                                          phone, has constructed, patented, and brought into practical
                                                                                                                          operation, an arrangement whereby the uses of the Tele
                                                                                                                          phone and the Phonograph are brought into harmonious
                                                                                                                          combination, and promise the greatest possible usefulness as
                                                                                                                          a commercial  auxiliary. Our readers, doubtless, perfectly
                                                                                                                          understand that the Telephone can only transmit sound, —
                                                                                                                          it cannot record or reproduce it.  This duty is left for the
                                                                                                                          Phonograph, a detailed description of which will be found
                                                                                                                          in the next article.   Mr. Edison, while attempting to remedy
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          the difficulty arising from the commingling of the sounds of

                                                                                                                          in close contiguity to the telephonic coil at each of the sta

                                                                                                                                           a
                                                                                                                          their original sonority and clearness, might be instantly con

                                                                                                                            Just sufficient alteration was made in the receiving-box at

                                                                                                                                      THOMAS A. EDISON        has recently invented an
                                                                                                                          MR.instrument     which is undoubtedly the scientific and
                                                                                                                          acoustic miracle of the nineteenth century.  It is called the
                                                                                                                          " Speaking Phonograph," or, as the Indian vernacular would
                                                                                                                          pertinently       render   it,   " The Sound-Writer    who Talks."
                                                                                                                          Though       faithfully records and reproduces the words, ca
                                                                                                                                      it
                                                                                                                          dences, and intonations    of the operator as strikingly and as
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:31 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243

                                                                                                                                                                     it
                                                                                                                                                                     is
                                                                                                                          ment, confounded with that natural phenomenon, the echo.
                                                                                                                          The reproduction by the phonograph differs as materially
                                                                                                                          from the echo as does the reflection of the human face in
                                                                                                                          water from its fixed retention in the photographic portrait.
                                                                                                                          The echo returns words only whtle you are present to speak
                                                                                                                          them   the phonograph
                                                                                                                                  ;                  an echo which will retain the very
                                                                                                                                                           is
                                                                                                                          tones and inflections of your voice for hundreds of years, and
                                                                                                                          reproduce them to your grandchild1en and great-grandchil
                                                                                                                          dren, so that they     will   be able to understand the peculiarities

                                                                                                                                                                        is

                                                                                                                             All talking-machines may be reduced to two types that of    ;
                                                                                                                          Prof. Fabcr, of Vienna, being the most perfect example of one
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          type (though that has since been discovered to be    mechana
                                                                                                                          ical trick and an unmitigated fraud), and that of Mr. Edison

                                                                                                                          entirely new departure in the science of Phonotypy, or Pho
                                                                                                                          nology, the results of which will not be fully developed for

                                                                                                                                                                 1

                                                                                                                          218      RECREATIONS IN POPULAR SCIENCE.                    [Garb1t.
                                                                                                                            Faber worked at the source of articulate sounds, and built
                                                                                                                          up an artificial organ of speech, whose parts, as nearly as
                                                                                                                          possible, perform the same functions as corresponding organs
                                                                                                                          in our vocal apparatus.    His "talking heads" were, some
                                                                                                                          twenty  or twenty-five years ago, the wonder of every great
                                                                                                                          city in Europe. The people were awe-stricken, and the sci
                                                                                                                          entific men of that day completely puzzled by them.   It was
                                                                                                                          claimed by the alleged inventor that a vibrating ivory reed,
                                                                                                                          of variable pitch, formed its vocal chords. There was an
                                                                                                                          oral cavity, the size and shape of which could be rapidly
                                                                                                                          changed by depressing the keys on a key-board.           A rubber
                                                                                                                          tongue  and   lips formed  the  consonants ;   a  little windmill,
                                                                                                                          turning in its throat, gave the roll of the letter R, and a tube
                                                                                                                          attached to its nose enabled it to give the nasal sound re
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:31 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          quired in speaking French. Such was the anatomy of this
                                                                                                                          really wonderful piece of mechanism ; but the vocal efforts
                                                                                                                          of this automaton generally resembled a person suffering
                                                                                                                          under the combined difficulty of a lisp and a curious imped
                                                                                                                          iment in his speech.
                                                                                                                             Faber attacked the problem on its physiological side only.
                                                                                                                          Mr. Edison adopts a radically different plan ; he essays to
                                                                                                                          solve the problem, not bv the source of origin of the vibra
                                                                                                                          tions which make articulate speech, but, viewing these vibra
                                                                                                                          tions as already made, it matters not how, he makes these
                                                                                                                          vibrations impress themselves on a sheet of metallic foil, or
                                                                                                                          revolving disc, and then reproduces from these impressions
                                                                                                                          the sonorous vibrations  which made them.
                                                                                                                             Faber based his invention on the reproduction of the me
                                                                                                                          chanical causes of the vibrations making voice and speech ;
                                                                                                                          Edison proceeded to obtain the mechanical effects of these
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          vibrations.   Faber reproduced the movements of our vocal
                                                                                                                          organs ;  Edison reproduced the motions which the membrana
                                                                                                                          tympanum, or drum-skin, of the ear has when this organ is
                                                                                                                          acted upon by the vibrations   caused by the movements      of   the
                                                                                                                          vocal organs.
                                                                                                                            One of Addison's humorous papers in the      " Tatler"   appears
                                                                                                                                                          2

                                                                                                                          Dutch and a French vessel,being caught in the Polar regions
                                                                                                                          and compelled to winter in Nova Zembla, the crews built

                                                                                                                          able to be heard, although each sailor seemed,      to himself, to
                                                                                                                          talk as well as ever.' This term of utter silence had contin
                                                                                                                          ued for more than three weeks, when with a turn of the wind

                                                                                                                          First, a crackling of consonants over their heads, then a
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:31 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243

                                                                                                                          pectedly made public, the punishments awarded to the cul
                                                                                                                          prits for their free speech, and other amusing incidents.
                                                                                                                            Now the phonograph surpasses this wild freak of humor
                                                                                                                          ous invention.     It catches and imprisons (and releases, at

Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          supposed to do ; but, instead of congealing those sounds in
                                                                                                                          the air, it solidifies them in a thin plate of metal, where they
                                                                                                                          are securely locked up for months, years, or centuries, or
                                                                                                                          until it pleases the holder of the metallic plate to let them
                                                                                                                          loose ; the very words, intonations, emphasis, and pauses
                                                                                                                          being accurately kept and reproduced at any time, and as

                                                                                                                             Experiments have proved that thirty-two simple vibrations
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:31 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          per second is the limit of grave sounds, while that of acute
                                                                                                                          sounds is seventy-three thousand in the same period of time.
                                                                                                                          Between these extreme limits the scale of sounds is contin
                                                                                                                          uous, so that there is an infinity of sounds having a different
                                                                                                                          pitch, appreciable to the ear, and passing from grave to acute,
                                                                                                                          and from acute to grave, by imperceptible degrees.       Below
                                                                                                                          and above the limits we have stated, the sound produced is
                                                                                                                          simply noise too indistinct to be appreciated by the ear, and
                                                                                                                          not to be compared or measured by musical sounds. One
                                                                                                                          can, therefore, scarcely imagine the rapidity of vibration that
                                                                                                                          will   be necessary to produce a  high musical note, the sharp
                                                                                                                          sound made in whistling, or the tinkling of a silver bell.
                                                                                                                          Yet the strings, the air, or the particles of the bell that emit
                                                                                                                          such sounds, pass through the required number of vibrations,

                                                                                                                          when it is desired graphically to record such a sound, deli

                                                                                                                          its membrane.      I   say expressly, quite close to its membrane,

                                                                                                                          228        RECREATIONS IN POPULAR SCIENCE.                  [Garb1t.
                                                                                                                          for the form of the trace obtained from a point attached to a
                                                                                                                          membrane vibrating under the influence of a compound
                                                                                                                          sound depends on the distance of the source of the sound from
                                                                                                                          the membrane, and the same      compound sound will form an
                                                                                                                          infinite number of different traces as we gradually increase
                                                                                                                          the distance of its place of origin from the membrane ; for,
                                                                                                                          as you increase the distance, the waves of the components
                                                                                                                          of the compound sound are made to strike on the membrane
                                                                                                                          at different periods of their swings.
                                                                                                                             " For example, if the compound sound is formed of six
                                                                                                                          harmonics, the removal of the source of the sonorous vibra
                                                                                                                          tions from the membrane, to a distance equal to one-fourth
                                                                                                                          of a wave-length of the first harmonic, will remove the sec
                                                                                                                          ond, third, fourth, fifth, and sixth harmonics to distances from
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:31 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          the membranes equal respectively to one-half, three-fourths,
                                                                                                                          one, one and one-quarter, and one and one-half wave-lengths.
                                                                                                                          The consequence evidently is, that the resultant wave-form
                                                                                                                          is entirely changed by this motion of the source of the sound,
                                                                                                                          though the sonorous sensation of the compound sound
                                                                                                                          remains unchanged.
                                                                                                                            " The above facts are readily proved experimentally by
                                                                                                                          sending a constant compound sound into the cone of Konig's
                                                                                                                          apparatus, while we gradually lengthen the tube between
                                                                                                                          the cone and the membrane next to the flame.     This is best
                                                                                                                          done by the intervention of one tube sliding in another, like          -
                                                                                                                          a trombone.    These experiments I have recently made with
                                                                                                                          entire success, and they explain the discussions which have
                                                                                                                          arisen between different observers as to the composition of
                                                                                                                          vocal and other composite sounds, as analyzed by means of
                                                                                                                          Konig's vibrating flames.
                                                                                                                               " These facts also show how futile it is for any one

                                                                                                                          of the harmonics of these voices, and with the different rela
                                                                                                                          tive intensities of these harmonics.

                                                                                                                            The instrument has no other parts but the cylinder and its
                                                                                                                          axis and the vibrator with its arm ; yet what wonderful
                                                                                                                          results are obtained ! A personal examination of this curi
                                                                                                                          ous invention at its' birthplace, the residence of Mr. Edison,
                                                                                                                          at Menlo Park, New Jersey, revealed the following facts as
                                                                                                                          to the practical commercial value of the invention.
                                                                                                                            The apparatus was made ready for operation, as we have
                                                                                                                          described above. The power was applied to the axle-crank,
                                                                                                                          and the operator    placed his mouth to the mouthpiece over
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:31 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          the diaphragm.      He spoke, sang, whistled, groaned, sneezed,
                                                                                                                          or laughed, as the whim seized him, until the tin-foil sheet
                                                                                                                          was filled to its outer limit. The vibrator arm was then un
                                                                                                                          damped and the point withdrawn until the cylinder had
                                                                                                                          revolved back to its original position.   Then the point of
                                                                                                                          the diaphragm was again applied securely to the cylinder
                                                                                                                          surface of tin-foil, on which the series of vibrations on the
                                                                                                                          diaphragm had been punctured by the sounds uttered in the
                                                                                                                          mouthpiece.    A paper funnel was now attached to the
                                                                                                                          mouthpiece   and over the diaphragm for the purpose of con
                                                                                                                          centrating the sound, the cylinder revolved as before, and the
                                                                                                                          phonograph repeated in a clear tone every word and sound
                                                                                                                          recorded on the tin-foil sheet.   The astonished listeners
                                                                                                                          heard issuing from the instrument the song, "John Brown's
                                                                                                                          body lies mouldering in the grave," &c, with the reinforced
                                                                                                                          chorus notes of" Glory, glory, hallelujah," &c, just as they
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          were sung into the mouthpiece.    The utterance of a formal
                                                                                                                          platform speech was given, with every change of intonation.
                                                                                                                          The emphases were well marked, and the pauses, inflections,
                                                                                                                          &c, as perfectly regulated and reproduced as if repeated by
                                                                                                                          the original speaker.   In a word, every sound of a pitch that
                                                                                                                          caused vibrations of the tin-type diaphragm, and thereby the
                                                                                                                                                        14

                                                                                                                          Garb1t.]      EDISON'S SPEAKING PHONOGRAPH.                 231
                                                                                                                          most minute impressions  of the pointer attached to it on the
                                                                                                                          tinfoil wrapper of the cylinder, was reproduced, no matter
                                                                                                                          how that sound was in accidental combination with others.
                                                                                                                             How the Sound 1s reproduced. — If a cause can be
                                                                                                                          reproduced by the agency of an effect, it is done on the pho
                                                                                                                          nograph.     To reproduce the sounds that caused the vibra
                                                                                                                          tions of the diaphragm and the puncturing of the tinfoil wrap
                                                                                                                          per of the revolving cylinder (as indicated in Fig. 28), it is
                                                                                                                          only necessary to make the pointer pass over and into these
                                                                                                                          punctures, and reproduce the vibrations in the diaphragm.
                                                                                                                          These latter, acting on the air, give to it the same relative
                                                                                                                          impulses, in the same order and energy, as were given it by
                                                                                                                          the organs  of speech or other causes of the original sound.
                                                                                                                          Hence, the conditions of atmospheric vibrations being alike in
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:31 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          both cases, the same effects must be produced ; and if the
                                                                                                                          sound of the human voice causes the diaphragm to vibrate and
                                                                                                                          mark the tin-foil, the inverse action of the tin-foil on the dia
                                                                                                                          phragm when the cylinder is revolved causes the reproduc
                                                                                                                          tionof the same series of vibration's, and consequently the
                                                                                                                          same sounds.  The process is so entirely simple that even
                                                                                                                          intelligent  observers find some difficulty in comprehending
                                                                                                                          it.   Their minds are prepared to wrestle with some scientific
                                                                                                                          difficulty, and they do not perceive how entirely devoid of
                                                                                                                          intricacy are the operations of cause and effect brought to
                                                                                                                          their notice in the phonograph.  Everybody knows that if a
                                                                                                                          drum is struck by a drumstick, a peculiar sound is emitted,
                                                                                                                          due to the vibrationsof the tightly stretched sheepskin head.
                                                                                                                          Those are at once understood to be the cause of the
                                                                                                                          sound. Now suppose it is possible to write down these vibra
                                                                                                                          tions, or rather that they should write themselves with a
                                                                                                                          minuteness and accuracy that could never be accomplished
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          by art, on a surface of such a character as would enable
                                                                                                                          them to be as accurately retraced by the instrument that writes
                                                                                                                          them, and that the said instrument retraces them with the
                                                                                                                          same energy as that     with which it wrote, it follows that   a
                                                                                                                          reproduction     of the vibrations will attend the retracing of

                                                                                                                                       RECREATIONS IN POPULAR SCIENCE.            [Garb1t.
                                                                                                                          their autographic characters, and of course the sound which
                                                                                                                          they in combination produce by their effect on the atmos
                                                                                                                          phere. This is exactly what occurs in the operation of the
                                                                                                                          phonograph.     The instrument is really more than what its
                                                                                                                          name expresses, because it not only autographically records
                                                                                                                          vibrations  due to sounds, but reproduces them again ; and
                                                                                                                          with them the sounds to which they owe their origin.
                                                                                                                            The same relation that photography bears to the repro
                                                                                                                          duction of images, that steam bears to locomotion and power,
                                                                                                                          that electricity bears to chemistry in the decomposition and
                                                                                                                          analysis of matter, and to the annihilation of distance and
                                                                                                                          time in the rapidity and accuracy of intercommunication, the
                                                                                                                          phonograph bears to the phenomenon of sound.         The tele
                                                                                                                          phone transmits sound by the aid of the electric current ; the
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:31 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          phonograph writes it in indelible characters, preserves   it,
                                                                                                                                                                                      as
                                                                                                                          it were, for all future time, and reproduces  as often as may
                                                                                                                                                                             it
                                                                                                                          be desired and in as many places at the same time as there
                                                                                                                          are facsimiles of the original sound-writing.
                                                                                                                             Among the experiments made recently at Menlo Park, and
                                                                                                                          elsewhere, was one to test the capacity of the phonograph

                                                                                                                                                     !
                                                                                                                          an utter confusion of sound such     medley would make, and
                                                                                                                                                               a
                                                                                                                          how difficult even   a  practised and attentive listener in     a
                                                                                                                          public hall or theatre would have found      to distinguish the
                                                                                                                                                                        it
                                                                                                                          consecutive utterances of the speaker, and catch the point of
                                                                                                                          witty or other interruptions.     Yet, judging from the tests
                                                                                                                          which were made at these places, the confusion of sound can
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          be accurately reproduced by the phonograph without involv

                                                                                                                             The Qual1ty of the Sounds. — 'Although the quality
                                                                                                                          of the sound as reproduced is not altered, its volume is ne
                                                                                                                          cessarily less than that of the original. The notes of the
                                                                                                                          higher pitch are given out with more distinctness, as a rule,
                                                                                                                          than those of the lower.    Whistling, no matter how rapid
                                                                                                                          the successions of notes, is- perfectly reproduced, and even
                                                                                                                          the nondescript sound of a low cough or sneeze is repeated
                                                                                                                          with startling accuracy. If the operator commences a sen
                                                                                                                          tence   in high-pitched voice, and gradually modulates the
                                                                                                                                       a

                                                                                                                          graph repeats, marking every change in the tone, and with
                                                                                                                          out any loss of distinctness.  Singing is reproduced accu
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-27 13:31 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101059540243
                                                                                                                          rately as to every note, distinctly as to the pronunciation
                                                                                                                          of every word, but with an approach to reediness. This
                                                                                                                          loss of volume observable in the first and necessarily experi
                                                                                                                          mental phonographs is due to the fact that the soft metallic
                                                                                                                          surface (tin-foil) that is punctured does not offer the resist
                                                                                                                          ance to the retracing of the stylus or needle of the diaphragm
                                                                                                                          sufficient to set up in the latter vibrations as energetic as
                                                                                                                          those developed by the original sound.     [This deficiency has
                                                                                                                          since been remedied by the substitution of a plastic material
                                                                                                                          capable of subsequent and gradual hardening.]      Hence very
                                                                                                                          loud sounds will be reproduced by the phonograph with a loss
                                                                                                                          of volume   but soft, low tones return from the instrument with
                                                                                                                                           ;
